My name is Kara. At least, that's my real name, but most people on this planet know me as Linda - or Supergirl.

When I was a baby, my own planet, Krypton, was destroyed - I don't know how. My parents had constructed a life pod, capable of an extended spaceflight - at least the twenty year journey to the planet Earth.

The pod was launched just minutes before Krypton exploded, and twenty years later, it crash landed on Earth. During the course of the journey, I developed, from a baby, to a young girl, teenager, and finally the woman I am today. The pod sustained me, protected me, educated me, but it was always lonely. I would often look out into space, and wonder if there was anyone else out there - or if I was the only one.

I longed for a companion, a friend. As the years rolled by, I began to try to sleep as much as possible, to avoid the pain of being awake and alone - so when my pod eventually did crash land on Earth, I wasn't awake to feel the impact.

When I did wake up, I knew instantly what had happened. During my education, I'd been told that the radiation from the yellow sun of this solar system would endow my body with fantastic strength and power. I felt better than I ever had in my whole life. I'd been looking forward to this for a long time.

I knew from my education that there was another Kryptonian on Earth, a man who had become loved among these people, and I was hoping to somehow find him. My parents knew what would happen to my body, and my mother had made me a costume so that I could be a superhero too. It's all I have of my home. I put it on, and tore my way out of the pod, unprepared for the blast of water that hit me full in the face as it flooded in. The pod had apparently landed in a river, and had already sunk to the bottom, but I got free and escaped to the surface, where I tested my new abilities for the first time.

I'd landed near a beautiful forest - my first taste of freedom. It's so big, everything seems to go on forever. I could hear and see and just sense far more than I'd ever been able to. I ran through it, testing my superspeed and just enjoying my freedom. I was flying, and I didn't even realise it, and then when I did realise, I could have cried with joy - I could fly! I took to the air, hurtling and circling and laughing in sheer delight at this amazing ability. I'd always looked forward to the day when I would gain my powers, and my freedom, and when I finally got them I hardly knew what to do first. Eventually, I landed back in the forest, and walked through it on foot - I wanted to savour every moment, every inch of my new surroundings. I was finally free.

When I wandered onto what I now know to be a road, I wasn't really thinking about anyone seeing me. I'd been alone all my life, and I hadn't really thought about what I would do when I eventually did meet someone.

Hugging them was not what I was expecting to do, but that was what I did when Nicola pulled up in her car. I was just overwhelmed by my first sight of another person - I needed to know that they were real.

I told her who I was and what had happened - of course, I had to demonstrate my powers. Nicola is wonderful - she's my friend, and that's everything I've ever wanted. She took me in, fed me, sheltered me, and she's kept my secret. Nicola lives - lived - alone, and her house is out here in the middle of nowhere. I like being here for her when she gets home, and I like being with her. I think she likes me too - she takes me out, she buys me things, and she said I can stay for as long as I want.

I need to repay her...we've talked about me having a double life, a dayjob...but at the moment I spend my days as Supergirl - saving people, helping people...and travelling. I've been here nearly two weeks now, and I love it. I can be in one country, watching the dawn of a new day, and then within seconds I can be on the other side of the planet watching the sun set. I just wish...Nicola could share it with me. I love her, and I wish she was like me...but how can I tell her, after all she's done for me? We're good friends...and, for her at least, that's where it ends. But I want more...I need to be loved.

I've got another problem too...since I came here, my appetite has soared. I can't stop eating. I never had this trouble back in the pod...but now I always seem to be eating...

It's showing. I've gained weight since I've arrived here - Nicola weighed me this morning, and I've gained nearly 100 pounds in 2 weeks, all of it fat. I'm looking at myself in the mirror now...shaking this belly I seem to have. There's a knock at the door.

"Come in, Nicola."

Nicola puts her beautiful head around the door. "Oh, Kara! I'll close the-"

"No, it's alright." I'd forgotten I was naked. "Come in."

Nicola comes in and closes the door, and I smile at her. "Are you off to work?" I ask.

"Yes...I'm going to ask if I get you as my assistant."

Wow..."Do you think they'd let you?"

She grins. "I'm the best journalist they have. If I say I need a photographer with me full time, I'll get it. And you will be it."

"You mean we can spend more time together!?!?"

"Sure. And I'll always let you go when you need to do your superhero stuff."

"Oh...Nicola, thank you so much!" I grab her and hug her tightly, and she hugs me back. She glances over my naked body, and I sigh. "I'm fat, aren't I?" I ask.

"Well...yes, you are. But there's nothing wrong with that."

"Your...newspapers...don't seem to think so." I sit down on the bed, thinking about what had been written. Nicola sits down with me and puts her arm around me.

"Kara, don't listen to them. You have nothing to be ashamed. They do. They're the ones who see you flying around doing nothing but good, and they pick on you for your weight."

I glance at the Supergirl costume on my bed and smile. It's a little embarassing actually...the world seems to see me as this mighty invincible goddess...I'm just...me.

"But it's not my fault it's happening." I say. "I mean, I'm the one that's eating, but only because the hunger gets so painful. It's the planet...whatever gave me my powers has done this."

"Hmm...well, maybe we should get you to a doctor."

She sighs. "If you carry on gaining weight...it's going to get even more obvious that you're Supergirl...look, promise me you won't just leave me...I need you."

I smile. "I would never leave you. You're all I have."

You hug again, and then Nicola looks at her watch. "Right, I'd better go or I'll be late - I'll see you later, Kara. Have fun."

"They don't understand my greatness. This device will effectively eliminate half the hero population! All I need to do is hit one woman with this, and she'll become so ravenously hungry that all she'll be interested in is eating eating and eating! She'll also get fat three times as quick, becoming an immobile blob in days! And best of all, this effect spreads to other women at the slightest touch! All the superheroines in Paragon will be fat masses, and there won't be a thing the heroes can do about it! AHAHAHAHA!"

He worked for a few minutes longer, until his machine was done. There was one small problem, though: He forgot the one danger of working underground in Paragon City.

The LOST might find you there.

As the monsters burst in, the mad scientist did the last thing he'd ever do as a living being: he activated his machine. Light burst from it, seeking out the first female bio-signature it could find...

151.content:
Men gasped, necks turning, even the shyest. Women blushed in shame and ground their teeth in anger. Bella was annoyed, but used to it--the envy and admiration came with beauty. And beauty was her power.

It was actually an effective deterrant to crime. This had surprised her. She'd moved to Paragon City, five years ago, to find work as a model. She had been enthusiastically signed, of course, but fired again almost as quickly. She was tall and slender, with a perfect waist, butt, breasts, lips, hair--she seemed to have strolled out of a Mucha painting, only with the slimness that is so fetishized in the modern world. Everything about her, taken separately, seemed to demand to be objectified, but when she took her turn on the catwalk or in front of the camera, her beauty seemed to flash out from her eyes like lightning and strike the photographers, the fashionistas, the oglers. They could DO nothing with it--could not possess it, could not package it. Rather, it possessed them, and they could only stare like dead men.

She had tried to look uglier for a while--but smearing the lipstick looked sensuous on that mouth; mussing her hair made it look alluringly tousled; covering up looked coy or classy, and her pose always had the same lightning-bolt effect on men. One magazine after another fired or refused to hire her, and, in the end, she had nowhere to turn, but the Academy, where, as we all know, the second-best superheroes--those with somewhat more...offbeat powers than flight or strength or invisibility are trained by some of the more eccentric and mysterious of the superhero populace. After graduating, she took the name Freya, after the Norse Goddess of love and beauty (she was hardly gifted with originality in anything besides her beauty), and began fighting crime as well as she could.

That had been about a year ago. She was still self-conscious about her beauty when she walked down the street, as other people are of a deformity, but making friends and rooming with other superheroes did much to lessen her feeling of freakishness which had not gone away even in the world of modeling. She--the most beautiful woman in the world--had been unable to meet men, for they would only gape at her, and lose the power of speech. Her roommates, Blur and Lantern, often commiserated with her, though one frequently had dates, and the other a fiancee. It wasn't fair, she thought, as she walked down the street--all eyes on her. Those other women--the ones who stared at her with hatred--could go to hell, if they thought this was easy.

She patrolled, dutifully, during the day. It didn't work as well at night, when whatever villain she was after couldn't see her to be stunned by her. It was just as well. She didn't have the luxury of an alter-ego, as a few of the stranger superheroes apparently did. "Bella" and "Freya" were interchangeable in the tabloids, which never had anything very juicy to report about her, unless they were lying. She was, after all, perfect. Even her crime-fighting career had been a moderate success so far. She had managed to arrest a gang of three men (who were, ironically, in the process of raping someone), and, even, single-handedly stopped a supervillain who was, after all, as vulnerable as any other man in THAT way.

She was thinking of none of this--save her loneliness--as she walked down Thomas Street, past the garage and into the shadier part of town. "These damn ugly cows," she muttered, encountering more disapproving looks. "Do they really think I'm after their men? Even if I could get a man, I wouldn't go after..."

An explosion. Underground.

"Well, shit."

Explosions were not her thing. She could tackle people, provided they could see her. But Lantern or Blur's powers would have been much more well-suited. This was their beat too, of course, but the two of them, Bella remembered as she reached for her cell phone, were gone for the day--Lantern with her fiancee, and Blur to her mother's.

"Well, shit." Smoke came from a subway entrance nearby. Bella bit her perfect lower lip and pulled down on her summer dress. This could get ugly.

1511.content:
There was time to kick off her high-heeled shoes. No time to think. There was time to put her golden blonde hair in a ponytail. No time to waver. There was time to push past the flocks of frightened people who issued from the metro and stared at her like she was crazy. No time to be afraid.

That is, not until she was in the metro. She raced toward the source of the smoke, inhaling prayers and exhaling the phrase, "Stupid Bella, Stupid Bella..." She really could get killed. A piece of debris, landing on her, would smash her as surely as it would any normal-looking woman.

Her eyes adjusted and watered as they searched for the source of smoke. She coughed. Then--she could almost swear it--she heard...voices? She forced another cough down and listened again.

Voices. Someone was trapped, all right. Somewhere. Sounded like they were--"Oh shit!"--they were on the other side of the tracks, weren't they?

No time to hesitate. She took a deep breath and prayed, prayed, prayed, jumped lightly in her yellow summer dress into the trench, prayed, prayed, ran, prayed, prayed, climbed up the other side. Coughed.

Listened again. Yes. Voices rose and fell, as if in conversation, coming from...aha. Only a few meters away, there was a door, which had been partly blown open in the blast. She ran to it, swallowing down her brain's protest of "Stupid, stupid, stupid."

There were corridors behind the door, as if in a hospital. The smoke was here as well, but the voices were...

The voices of the LOST. She nearly walked into the three forms that squatted over the pieces of what had once been a man, talking pleasantly--dinnertime conversation. She stopped and stared, transfixed by their hideous faces as they, looking up at her, were transfixed by her unearthly beauty. She began, tremblingly, to move despite her horror. They had no such freedom. They were, at least, male LOST. Taking out her cell phone, Bella dialed the first superhero's number she could find. Shitshitshitshit. No dial tone. Of course, Bella. Now what? Oh god, they were hideous. Now what? If she even turned away for a moment, they might snap out of it and...

Suddenly a bright flash. Another explosion. Bella screamed, and she was knocked off her feet by light. She sat up, shaking her head, and while she was still shaking with fear, she felt something else as well...something quite strange. She could feel the light still, all over her, though she could not see it. Her body felt warm as she stood up to leave, and she could not shake the feeling that something was different.

15111.content:
The LOST still stared up at Bella, still awed by her beauty. But a queer expression was coming over their--faces?--as well. It was one of...interest? Why were they watching her as if there was something strange about her now?

She looked down at her bare, scraped, slender feet and legs, her torn summer dress draped over her breasts and poetic waist. Nothing here seemed out of order. Not to her eye. But, now that you mentioned it, she did feel rather...

"OoOoOOh," she suddenly cried, leaning against a wall to prevent a second fall. There was no pain, but the warmth she felt over her body was increasing, and it was as though all of her muscles were twitching rapidly. She glared at the LOST. "What did you...?" Then, suddenly, to her horror, and in a way that certainly did not suit a superheroine...she began to giggle.

She could NOT help it. And she was glad none of her colleagues was there to see it. The twitching in her sides, in her--breasts?--were there muscles there?--in her thighs and...and...everywhere, was unbearable. "Ahhahahaheeheehehheh.." She began to collapse, still leaning against the wall, and as she clutched her sides, she realized something was very, very wrong.

It was like feeling someone else's stomach. Her fingers felt--rather than the expected toned muscles beneath the dress--small rolls of excess flesh. She instantly withdrew her hands in shock, and looked down. As she did so, she noticed that her chin, disconcertingly, rubbed against itself. She also saw that her breasts had swollen to twice their size. And behind them, slowly, a heaviness grew, and she watched in horror and fascination as a belly--so alien to her!--rose behind them like a yellow sun behind mountains. Her stomach and chest were continually expanding as though she could not stop breathing in, exhale though she might. In an entirely new mode of panic (though still unable to quell the giggling fits that accompanied multiplying fat cells), she felt her face. It now possessed a triple chin, and not even a trace of the once-austere cheekbones.

Laughing past all control, she looked at the LOST who now looked--if it were possible for spooks to be spooked--horrified. "K-killl m--" She began to say, but was suddenly overwhelmed with a real, sharp pain, and aware of the fact that she could no longer breathe.

Realizing her bulk was now straining the limits of her little yellow dress, she swung her arms (flab now hanging off them) behind her to her imprisoned back, and desperately grappled with the zipper for relief. But her expanding body did not wait for her clumsy, fat fingers, and, suddenly, --Shhhrriipppp--the cute little sun-dress was demolished by her widening ass and bursting tummy, and hung in yellow ribbons between folds of fat. Bella cried out, as though in labor, then lost consciousness.

She was awakened, very shortly thereafter, by a sharp tooth entering her right flank. Grunting, she sat up, gasped and bellowed. The LOST one, suddenly overawed, backed away quickly as Bella stood to her feet with less difficulty than she would have anticipated.

The 250-pound woman bellowed again, like an animal, then, coming to her senses, cried out, "YOU! YOU did this to me!" The LOST cowered before her--this time, not before a stunning beauty, but rather as before a more primitive, shapeless, nature-goddess of the earth.

My God, a part of her thought. Are they actually afraid of me?

She took a threatening step toward the crouching shapes, to see. They were, indeed, afraid of this unpredictable and suddenly monstrous woman, but rather than running away, they sprang on her like cornered animals. Just fantastic, part of her thought, as one fastened itself to a new fold of flesh on her side, and another began to claw at her back. Now I am nude, obese, and fighting off ghouls in a subway. Good move, Bella.

But the larger part of her was incensed, as only a goddess can be. "How DARE you?" she screamed, despite realizing that she had, only moments before, ASKED them to kill her. She found--the surprise of it would sink in later--that she could move quite freely, despite her new body, and in a rage she picked up two of the LOST, and hurled them against the wall. And suddenly, despite her bulk, she felt marvelous; euphoric--if still wrathful. Was it--was it adrenaline, this new strength that filled her body as surely as the warmth and fat had? She turned on the remaining member of the LOST.

"For what you have done to me, creature"--she spoke in a husky, dangerous whisper--"For what you have done to me, I will hunt down you and your kind. I will destroy every last one of you." The ghoul's face contracted in what--possibly--was relief at the mercy shown to messengers. It turned to scamper away, but was seized by its leg.

"I didn't say," laughed the goddess, "I didn't say I was going to let you warn them."

If you had been on the street above, in a rare silent moment, you might have heard the faint yet bloodcurdling cry of a ghoul being torn apart. If you had waited on that same street until nightfall, you would have seen emerge, as inconspicuously as possible, a rather obese woman with a construction-site tarp pulled about her naked form for modesty's sake. But if you had approached the woman to ask her what in heaven's name she was doing, you would have been struck, like lightning, by the wild beauty of her eyes and tousled hair, the merciless grimace of a full mouth and clenched, perfect teeth, and--probably--by a plump, bloodstained fist jutting out from between the folds of tarp. "I'm doing my job," you would have heard a husky, yet alluring voice shout, as you coughed and wheezed. Then, a little further off, you would have, possibly, heard giggles and sobs.

151111.content:
"All I'm saying," continued Felicity, in as quiet a voice as possible, "is that it might not be such a bad thing. She's been beautiful her whole life. This will build character."

Francesca, sitting on the sofa of the living room, looked incensed and scandalized. "Madonna, Fay-leese, how you can say that? It is a gran tragedy! She was soooo beautiful, an' now!" Tears filled the empathetic Sicilian's eyes.

"Shhhh," returned Felicity. "She's fat, but she's not deaf, you know."

"She sleeping," said Francesca. "Is very sad. Maybe we help her loose weight?"

"Of course we can, but only if she wants us to. I can offer to run with her in the mornings, but I think right now is too soon. I think she's still pretty sensitive."

"We can' jus' say nothing. Madonna! Act like everything is just normal? The poor girl! We gotta talk to her." Francesca, known as "Lantern" in the superhero community, was growing progressively darker as the night wore on, and Felicity knew what that meant. Francesca's moods, which ranged from euphoric to deeply depressed, usually corresponded with her power, the ability to absorb or reflect light. She was, essentially, at 23-year-old mood ring. At the moment, her hair was jet black, and her skin looked deeply tanned, almost African.

"No, Lantern, it's too soon to help her find solutions. It happened like two days ago. Let her grieve for a bit. I've been a few pounds overweight myself before, and it wasn't terrible...I just had to learn to be disciplined and rely on mys--"

"Fay-leese! It's notta the same thing at all, an' you know that!" Remembering herself, this time, Lantern quieted down. "She gain what? Sixty-five kilo--sorry, hundred fifty pounds? In less than a minute, an' you think that a normal? None o' her clothes fit no more! None! An' you say discipline! What would you really do if that was you?"

Felicity (called Blur because of her powers of speed) pursed her thin lips uncomfortably. Fine. She'd never admitted it when the girl still had a perfect figure, but she'd always been a bit jealous of Bella. Francesca seemed to be the only one who never was--Francesca, who, while pretty, was neither as thin or as gorgeous as either of them. And Francesca was probably right. "Shit," said Felicity. "Yeah, you're probably right."

"'Course I'm right." Large, black eyes flashed with anger. The negative emotions were beginning to come on.

"All right, all right," sighed Felicity, standing up, and turning off the television which had provided some level of camouflage to their conversation. Let's go check on the girl. You realize we're probably only waking her up?"

"Even so, she need us. She need somebody." They walked down the hallway to Bella's bedroom door.

Felicity raised her fist hesitated a moment before knocking, and...

"I know you've been talking about me," came a muffled voice from behind the door. It still surprised both girls how rich the voice now sounded.

"Of course we have," said Felicity. "Can we come in?"

"Sure."

The door creaked open. Both girls, if they didn't gasp, at least hesitated a moment, a bit stunned. They had expected to find their roommate lying in bed, surrounded by tissues, or with the covers pulled over her head and ample body. They'd expected her eyes to be puffier than even the excess weight had made them, and her hair to be disarranged, without a trace of makeup. So what they saw, understandably, took them by surprise.

Their roommate, Bella, was standing up, on her two legs, each--now--as thick around as her entire body had been three days before. They were surprised, first, that she was wearing boots, which had a slight heel and were laced up, but looked hardy enough for any outdoor hike. Above these, her exquisitely tanned but huge legs were bare, up until a kind of black leotard, which covered her bulging upper thighs, butt, tummy and prodigious breasts, ending at her neck. Painted over the leotard, stretched over her belly and breasts, was the image--a logo--of a sun shining. Her full face--still oddly beautiful and full of energy, like the faces in a Rubens painting, or a heavier version of Mucha's "Ivy," was made up, and she was, at the moment, gathering her golden ringlets from around her golden shoulders, and putting it up in a ponytail.

"Freya!" exclaimed Francesca. What you wearing? What-a-you doing?"

"I'm not Freya anymore," said Bella, grimly checking herself, just for a moment, in the mirror.

"What in the world are you doing? And what are you wearing?" asked Felicity.

"It's my new costume," chirped Bella, in a voice that approached cheerfulness.

"It's nice," said Felicity, tentatively. "Umm...why are you wearing it now?"

"I have to go patrol."

"But...you don't patrol at night. You never did, even when you...had..."

"I have new powers now."

"Do you?" Felicity's voice sounded worried.

"Yes." Bella straightened her hair.

"And what are those?"

Bella turned from the mirror, and walked up to Felicity, who backed away unconsciously. Bella got closer, until she was in Felicity's face, her belly touching Felicity's toned abs. "To get really annoyed at skinny little bitches who think being fat builds character."

Before Felicity could back away, she felt herself being lifted--easily--by the former beauty goddess, scraping past belly and breasts, until she was held over Bella's head.

"Freya, put her down!" screamed Lantern.

Bella laughed. "My name's not Freya anymore, Francesca! You can call me the Amazon."

With that, Felicity felt herself tossed lightly into Bella's bed, as the Amazon slammed the door behind her. She heard Francesca cry out, "Bella, eh, come back! Where are you going?"

"Sorry, Fran," came Bella's voice, further away. "I have a new mission now. I've finally found my place." And the Amazon was gone.

"Are you okay, Fay-leese?" cried Lantern, coming to the side of the bed, where the girl was slowly rising.

"Yeah, I'm fine," answered Felicity. Might have pulled something, but I'm okay."

"We should follow her, yeah?"

"Yeah. Probably."

"You think she gonna be all right?"

"I have no idea. Not if I get through with her first, she won't."

1511111.content:
Boots thudded down the street. A large, dark form, with bare legs, arms, and blonde hair made its way down Thompson, toward the metro, toward the last place she had seen the LOST. Hopefully, she thought, the few people loitering on the street would not recognize her as the same superheroine. Hopefully there would be no pity or attention paid her. If she had her way, she would not often be above ground, anyway. There was a war to wage down there, in the sewers, metro systems, in the dark places of the earth.

She rounded a corner. She was in sight of the metro station. It wasn't that she wanted revenge. Well, maybe it was. Be that as it may, she had always been...unsure about her status as a superhero before. She had not been sure what her "mission" was, or how well her powers complemented her vocation. But now, it all fit. She had come to the city, trained as a hero, lost her figure and her beauty because...because it was her destiny to destroy the LOST. It of course helped that the vampiric creeps had apparently rigged up a machine that had caused her to gain (what was at last count) 175 pounds.

Whatever their motives behind doing it, though, they had, apparently, not foreseen the superhuman strength and agility that would come with the weight gain. She wondered how much of her sizeable body was made up of excess fat, and how much was pure muscle mass. She was in the subway now, and over the pathetic bars that were designed to keep pedestrians out. As if the threat of being eaten by the LOST was not enough.

She made for the alley where it had all gone down. She didn't expect to find any more LOST there, but where else was there to start? At the moment, most in the city were even afraid to go out at night because of their activity. Once she rid the metropolis of them, then she, who had been so disliked while she was beautiful, would be beloved by...

My gosh. She stopped. But it was creepy down here. Really creepy. She looked around and felt, despite her size, suddenly very small. She'd planned to go down there like a primordial goddess of light expelling the darkness from beneath the earth, but at the moment she felt like nothing more than a fat girl underground. In a silly outfit, to boot. There was that creepy passage, up ahead. Ugh. Her steps slowed, and she realized that thundering through the hallway--or anywhere--was probably not the best idea.

And, the door to the passage was now bolted shut. Oh well. We tried, she thought.

Then, suddenly, she heard a sound on the other side of the door.

"Shit."

1511112.content:
The doorbell rang. Dr. Gerard, one of the many biologists specializing in metahuman sciences in Paragon City, looked up from a book that even he found boring.

"It's one in the morning," he mused, rubbing the back of his neck as he sat up. He walked to the kitchen pantry of his house, which doubled as a security station, and looked in the monitor. "Hmm...wow, rather...largeish...woman at the door. Don't recognize her. Better bring the gun, just in case. One never knows."

It was technically summer, but the air was still cool at night, and the woman, to his surprise, had nothing more on than a swimsuit-shaped leotard and boots. She looked oddly familiar, and--despite her weight--oddly beautiful as well. My god, what eyes. How strange.

"Can I help you, miss?" he asked, after staring for just a moment.

"Yes, Dr. Gerard," said the young woman, her ample cheeks turning slightly red. "Do you mind if I come in?"

"Umm...I'm sorry ma'am, but I don't just let strange women...wait, do I know you?"

"Dr. Gerard!" The girl was visibly distressed. He looked at her again. Those amber-colored eyes, the golden ringlets, the perfect teeth and lips, it couldn't be, but it couldn't not be...

"Bella? Oh my gosh, Bella Hauge? What--what happened, girl? Come in, come in!"

An hour later, Bella was drinking tea, and, despite herself--with increased weight, it seems, really did come increased appetite--eating most of a tray of ginger cookies Dr. Gerard had set out for her. He had been her favorite professor at the Academy, though they had only, until now, communicated by e-mail due to the odd affect her powers once had on all males. She had always harbored a secret crush on the man, who was only just into his forties and had all his hair, unlike most of the professors at her old school. She tried to sound intelligent and brave, as they had their first face-to-face interview.

"...so, after that," she concluded, "I went back home, bought this costume online, and I really think it is my destiny to take on the LOST. And to repay them for what they did to me."

The doctor seemed lost in thought.

"And so, I changed my name to The Amazon. Because I'm strong now."

The doctor still didn't answer. He stared, absent-mindedly, down the hall.

"And I was wondering if you could help me, because you've always known more about the LOST than most."

The doctor's jaw tightened, as if he was thinking deeply about something.

"Dr. Gerard!"

"Oh, I'm sorry, my dear! Just...lost in thought, like we absent-minded professors tend to be. Where did you say this place was, that you saw the LOST?"

Bella patiently repeated the description of the laboratory.

"And what...did the man look like, who you saw them attacking?"

Bella told him.

"Bella, I am not so sure that your...vendetta against the LOST is well-founded," said Dr. Gerard, after a moment.

Bella was not surprised. "Look, Dr. Gerard, I really appreciate your concern. But I need to do this. I really...for the first time, I feel like I know what I'm supposed to do as a superhero. It's...it's all I have...now..."

Oh God, she thought. I'm crying. If I were still Freya it would look cute, but who wants to see a whale like me crying in his office. I wish my stomach and damn CHIN would not jiggle like that every time I sob!

What she said was, "...I--I'm sorry..."

Suddenly, she was shocked to feel his hand--surprisingly rough--stroking the tears back from her cheek. And his voice--surprisingly soft--soothing her.

"Hey, Bella...Bella...look at me. Don't cry." With a start, she looked up, and saw he was right next to her. My God, had he always been that cute?

"What I meant," he said, "was that your vendetta is not justifiable, because, one, the LOST didn't take everything from you at all."

"N-no? Well, look at me, Dr. Gerard, I'm--"

His voice shook a bit, with passion, "--YOU are every inch as beautiful as you ever were. Never has a more beautiful woman crossed this threshold."

"Are you JOKING?"

"Do you have any IDEA," he said, "how hard it is to keep from kissing you right now?"

She was stunned.

"Second of all," he said, "I am not so sure it WAS the LOST who did this to you. There was a man I knew, who--"

Now it was his turn to be surprised, as she stood up, pressing all of her against him, filling his mouth with hers. Maybe it was stupid, they both thought, but I need this right now.

Sanity kicked in before they consummated anything (and indeed, her costume was incredibly difficult to get off, unlike her hair-band), and for a moment, they lay on the floor of his study.

"You taste like ginger cookies," he said, still dazed.

"And you taste like science," she responded. "Hey, what was it you started to say before? About the man you knew?"

The doctor's expression suddenly changed. "Bella, you'd better sit down." His face was conflicted, as if he was struggling against something.

"I...had a friend," he began, "and we worked on some projects together...projects having to do with...the metabolism of metahumans."

He had her full attention now.

"We had very...interesting plans, I guess you might say. Both of us were a little obsessive about our subject. As you have realized by this point, we both preferred the...rounder, softer kind of figure on a woman, and we were...disappointed that so many superheroines were...well, far from our ideal. It may have been wrong, but we aimed to change that. After a while, I, however, was hired by the Academy. I got a new lab, and, increasingly, the work that Abraham--that was his name--and I were doing, was pushed to the side. He called me a traitor, and when I got a new lab with my Academy paycheck, and started to work on my own...he swore never to work with me again. He was, by that point, on his way to discovering some...ray...that causes fat cells to multiply in the female body...

"What?" was all Bella could manage.

"But I stopped checking in on him at our subterranean lab, after a while."

"What?" This was more than she could have thought possible.

"You...so...you're an expert on THIS?" She dug her hands into her belly, pulling at two fistfuls of flesh.

"It would seem so," said Dr. Gerard.

"Well, then," she said, calmly, "you can...you can help me get back to...to normal, then, can't you? I mean, you can find a way to reverse it, if anyone can!"

He stood up. "Bella. I certainly could."

"Oh, thank you so much!" she almost screamed in relief. "Oh, I'm so glad I came to you!"

He had an odd look on his face for a moment, but he smiled all the same. "Just...let's go to MY lab. I'll fix you up with the right pills."

Bella was beaming. "Oh, thank you so much, Doctor." She walked ahead of him, down the corridor of the house. Thank God. It was all going to be fine. Everything was going to be--"

And suddenly, the sound of a stun gun. Everything. Goes. Black.

151111211.content:
Bella stared, momentarily spellbound by her own revived beauty.

She called to Dr. Gerard several times, but, though she heard someone moving through the house, no one walked through the laboratory door. Slowly, feeling began to come back into her arms and legs, and she managed to stand, holding on to the table next to her at first, then, like a toddler, one step at a time, she approached the mirror.

She was, she realized, even more beautiful than she had been previously, despite the paleness that attended her unconsciousness. How had he done it? She turned her head, searching for any sign of her previous plumpness, but nothing of the sort was to be found--where there had been a double chin and swollen cheeks, there was now a slender neck, visible cheekbones...it was as though her more fleshy self had all been a dream, and the fat had simply melted off in her sleep.

She looked from one side to the other, then in the corners of the room for any hidden cameras, and she easily slipped off the black suit with its symbol which now had little meaning for her. Here, at last, was her body--gloriously trim and yet voluptuous...and without so much as a stretch mark. Her tummy was tight, her breasts, legs and buttocks, firm and toned, with just the right amount of softness. Her skin, she noticed, was softer than it had ever been before--almost tender--and it seemed to glow pink in the light, rather than tan.

Bella laughed, suddenly, threw the suit back on--now large enough for two of her--and ran out the door into the hallway.

And there, suddenly, she stopped. Before her, Professor Gerard stood, staring.

Staring, like every man stared, at her "perfect" body.

She hoped they would still be able to communicate, like they had before--the night before, when there had been ginger cookies and witty conversation and love. She tried.

"Dr. Gerard, look! I'm back to my old self!"

He stared. Her heart sank.

"Thank you so much."

He stared. Fighting back tears, she walked up to him, and kissed him, long and hard. He didn't respond, comatose on his feet.

"Thank you."

Walking out of the house, clutching her clothes tightly about her in daylight, Bella walked right into a slightly rounder girl in the shadows--or, at least, a girl who seemed to gather shadows around her, even in the middle of the day.

"Ey, watch where you going, Miss! Can't you see I'm standin' right he--Bella? Madonna, Bella, is that you again?"

"Francesca! What are you doing here?"

"We follow you, Blur and me. We figure you are all right because you at Dr. Gerard's house, but we wanna make sure, so we take it in shifts to stand guard here. Bella, you thin again."

"Yeah, I know!" said Bella, trying to sound more enthusiastic than she felt. "I can't believe it. Dr. Gerard did it...somehow. I'm not sure how."

"You didn't ask...oh."

"Yeah, he no talk-y."

"You make funna my accent jus' now."

Bella had forgotten how Francesca--Lantern--got when she was in her dark mood. "Let's go on back to the house, huh?"

Francesca complied. "You make fun o' me, Bella. Nobody take me serious. Also, now I'm the fat one again."

Oh great. She had heard this speech before. There was no reasoning with Lantern during either stage of her energy cycle. She sucked the positive energy out of the atmosphere immediately around her during the first phase, looked, talked, and was powerless like, any human being during the second phase, and was manically happy and--literally--radiant during the third--shooting energy at anyone and everyone. Bella held her arm, which felt a little like dry ice, as they walked together down the street and past the metro that had started it all.

"Francesca...speaking with authority as someone who actually WAS fat...there is NOTHING wrong with your size."

Francesca, of course, didn't listen, and continued to complain--though she couldn't have been more than 145 pounds, thought Bella--that she was, in fact, monstrous compared to her two roommates, and that she can just tell that her fiance, Jack is turned off by it, and what if she keeps putting on weight and ends up completely...

Bella looked around as they talked. More glares from other women. More stares from men. For some reason it bothered her more, now, the effect her stupid powers had. And she thought of Dr. Gerard. How he had held her. How he had kissed her. How he hadn't cared that she was...was...

"Fat. Ev'ry day, I jus' feel fatter," Francesca was crying, now. Soon, Bella knew, the negative part of the cycle would be over, and the girl would be laughing and thoughtful again. Meanwhile, Lantern had Jack, and who did Bella have? What boy, anywhere, in the world, was capable of having a relationship with her?

During the days and weeks that followed, even as she found satisfaction in looking at the pink, taut skin of her new/old body, and trying on cute outfits at department stores...she often found herself touching her lips, and holding her own arms, and missing the--for her, new--feeling of being embraced by a man. What was the use of a perfect body if there was no one to hold it?

Walking into her room on a sunny, but depressing day, worn out from the isolation which cut into her like a cold win, beautiful Bella looked in her dresser mirror where she had once seen an angry, massive version of herself--but one capable of being loved--and she came to a realization.

"I'm gonna die alone," she said to herself. "Unless something changes, I'm gonna die alone."

And with that, she made up her mind.

15112.content:
Thankfully, the flash of light that struck Bella had further disoriented the LOST, and she was able to back away from them, very slowly, back up the corridor, looking behind her in case there were more.

So her power, apparently, worked on male ghouls as well as men. That was good to know. Though she didn't anticipate coming underground again anytime soon. Soon, though, she would be far enough away from them that they could no longer see her clearly, and her spell would lose its effect. Perhaps her pheromones would linger in the air, for a while.

She also, however, felt something warm and active lingering deep within her, as though a fire had settled in her stomach. It felt very odd, but not unpleasant.

"You stay back," she shouted at the ghouls down the corridor, in what her roommates had once termed "The goddess voice." She could no longer see them. That made her nervous. She was out in the metro tunnel now, which was full of smoke, but also (comparatively) of light. They probably, at least, would not dare to come out here during the day, but she did not want to take chances. Turning on the heels of her now-badly-scraped and filthy feet, she ran.

I hate this city, she thought, as she emerged from the tunnel, squinting green eyes, and noticing that, as usual, men within a ten-foot radius were staring at her, women frowning.

"Oh come on," she mumbled. "My feet are bleeding and black with dirt, nails broken, my dress is torn, and my hair is in a ponytail, for God's sake." What she said aloud was, "Uh...citizens...has anyone seen my shoes?"

After ten minutes of searching (they were her favorite pair), the heels were recovered, and she walked back toward her apartment, the warm glow still crackling inside her. Suddenly, she realized she was terribly hungry.

There's nothing in the fridge, she thought. Nothing good, anyway. Just vegetables, fruit, a few flavor ices. Milk. She would have to go grocery shopping, she realized with dismay. She felt so hungry she was trembling, a little, as she walked up her street now, which was wickedly slanted. And sitting there--on her own front porch--she suddenly noticed a young man. He looked up at her, expectantly, in the midst of fidgeting.

"Are you Bella Hauge?" he asked, looking up. He was olive-skinned and hairy, but had elegant cheekbones and long, graceful limbs, like her. He was not handsome--not conventionally, anyway, but there was a beauty about him.

"Um, yeah," said Bella. "Can I help you with something?"

"Herman O' Lymp," said the man, grinning a bit and looking her in the eye. "I wrote you on craigslist yesterday. Tried to call, but it went to voicemail. Are you still interviewing roommates?"

Bella was dumbstruck, because Herman didn't seem to be. Every man--EVERY man--with whom she had ever attempted conversation--save for her own father--every man, since she had turned fourteen--had been unable to utter more than a few coherent syllables in her presence. But this man had looked her in the eyes and answered, with perfect poise, "I wrote you on craigslist."

"Oh, shit," she said, "I'm--I'm sorry, I totally forgot. Hold on...uh...come in. She fidgeted with her keys. Sorry, what was your name again?"

"Herman," said Herman.

"I'm Bella."

"I know that," said Herman, smiling again. Shoot, she looked like an idiot. But a man was talking to her! Actually...wow.

"So, let me show you around. This is the living room, and..."

Her speech was suddenly interrupted by a terrific noise, issuing--to her horror--from inside her stomach. It had tried, hard, to be patient, but it could not endure any longer without nourishment.

"Oh shit--I mean, uh--excuse me, I'm just really, really hungry all of a sudden."

"Ah. So you're mortal, after all?" he said, graciously dismissive. "Are utilities included in the price?"

"Yes, except for--" Again, there was a loud growl, and she felt suddenly that she was about to pass out. "I'm so sorry, Herman, um...look, would you be okay having this interview for dinner--I mean, over--dinner?" She realized to her horror that she was asking him on a date.

"I was about to suggest that," said Herman. "I'm pretty hungry as well, don't worry."

"Okay, great. Um...I'm just going to go change out of this." She showed him the frayed end of her dress. "And wash off a bit. Just feel free to look around while I do."

She nearly ran to her room. What was wrong with her? More importantly, was there anything--anything at all--in her room to eat? She ransacked her portmanteau, her stomach crying like a baby all the while. This had never, ever happened. In a bottom drawer, mercifully, she came across her salvation in the form of a few oatmeal cookies, which trembled in her hands as she crammed them into her mouth. The acidic complaints in her stomach turned--for just a brief moment--back into the warm glow, which spread through her body. It felt--wonderful. She stripped off her dress, and looked--approvingly for a moment--at her golden skin and hair in the mirror. Her mother had been Italian, and her father, Norwegian-by-way-of-Minnesota, and the most desirable genetic traits of each race had blended beautifully to produce blonde ringlets, a honey-colored complexion, and a perfect body that was slender without looking barren. She had a single freckle on her shoulder, perfect lips, and eyes which were, at some times, piercing green, and at others, the color of coffee.

Relax, Bella, she thought. How could he not love this? She told herself she wasn't being vain, just honest. It was her power, after all...which didn't seem to work on him. That was very, very strange. She stopped thinking to wash her feet in the bathtub, arrange her hair, and pull on her favorite pair of jeans--low-cut, slender. Over her well-filled bra she slipped a lovely little green shirt that did not quite fall to her navel. She examined herself again, fastening earrings, but was disturbed, again, by another slight groan from her stomach.

She was indignant. "I just gave you some food," she said, aloud, looking down at her perfect navel. "And I let you out. You have to behave now."

She walked out of her room, to find Herman looking at a few of the pictures on the wall, and straightening them.

"Ready?" she asked.

"Absolutely," he said, looking at her, appreciatively but guardedly. "Where would you like to go?"

"Doesn't matter," she shrugged. Her stomach grumbled at this, and she almost slapped it.

151121.content:
"So your name is Bella. You don't LOOK Italian." Herman stirred his coffee, and looked her in the eyes--again!--it was almost impertinent the way he did that.

"Yes," she answered, staring down at the single bran muffin she had opted to buy. She had been the one who suggested the bakery. Why? It was this damn man who had thrown her off her guard. There was nothing even particularly attractive about him, other than the stormy grey eyes and curly black hair. His nose was too large, and he was, she thought, much too hairy and skinny. Yet she hadn't been able to focus since she'd seen him, sitting on her doorstep, straightening her flower pots and grinning saucily up at her. Though maybe it wasn't entirely his fault. The events of the day had not exactly been typical. And the hunger she felt, it was not exactly typical, either. Huh. Shoot, she realized. She should say something.

"Are you okay?" he said, beating her to the punch.

"Not really," she said. "Sorry. I've had a bizarre day."

"Anything you care to share?"

She shuddered at the thought of the LOST. "No, not especially," she said. "I'd rather not talk about it."

"Good. I always prefer to talk about shallow things, anyway." He grinned with half of his mouth, and fixed the collar of his small shirt. How was he so fidgety, but so confident at once? "So...take two. Your name is Bella. But you don't look Italian."

"Well, you certainly don't look Irish, Mr. O'Lymp."

"Did I ever say I was?" He flipped half of his collar up again.

"Are you Ara--Middle Eastern?"

"NO!" he said, very loudly. A couple at the next table looked over. "Sorry," he said to them. "No, Bella, Bella, I'm Greek!"

She was a bit embarrassed, at first of her faux pas, but even moreso because of this dark stranger's behavior. Maybe he wouldn't be an ideal housemate although, admittedly...she was attracted to him. She felt her stomach rumble, and decided to put him on the defensive before he could hear it. "Huh. Weird last name for a Greek--O'Lymp."

Herman shrugged. "Yeah, well...weirder for a Turk."

Bella could feel her stomach begin to rumble again, and she slurped some coffee in an attempt to cover the noise. She wanted to annhilate that muffin stump (it mocked her!), but she did not want to eat faster than Herman. It was agony.

"S-so, Herman," her teeth chattered, as she began to shake, she hoped, imperceptibly, "So, Herman, do you think you could really put up with living with THREE girls? That's a lot of drama."

"Good. Greeks invented drama," he said, eyes shining, pleased with himself. "You should see how it is in my family."

She laughed, relaxing a bit. "Well, that's good." Then, automatically, before her brain was aware of it, her hands stuffed the rest of the muffin past her glossy lips and into the oblivion of her mouth and stomach. What the hell? She thought. Nice, Bella. Now he'll think you're a--

"Nice one!" Herman crowed, and to Bella's mortification, the occupants of three tables looked at them--him, juggling rolled-up straw papers, and her with a mouth full of bran muffin. "It's so refreshing when a pretty girl isn't afraid to--"

Yes, yes, she had heard this from too many guys. 'It's nice when a pretty girl isn't afraid to eat, provided she stays unrealistically thin all of her life.' There's the rub. She swallowed, took a sip of coffee, and started to say so, when...

Suddenly, she was distracted from even the boy in front of her. It was a GOOD muffin. It was the best muffin, in fact, that she had ever tasted. The warmth within her surged and she had to stop herself from groaning in pleasure. She was still so hungry, though.

"You okay?" asked Herman. This was, she realized, probably the weirdest "date" the poor boy had ever been on.

"I'm sorry, I just haven't eaten all day," she lied. "Um, I'll be right back." She rose, thanking God that the pastry counter and bathrooms were in another room of the bakery/coffee-shop. As she strode toward the counter, she realized that she'd somehow given herself a wedgie. Her pants felt strange, as well. She would adjust that when she got to the bathroom, she thought. Right now, she did not have the patience even to look down.

The barista gave her an odd look. "Hey, up here," she said, impatiently. "One cookie, please."

"Of course, miss." The barista--her name was Alaina--looked at her again. "Will there be anything else?"

Well, since she asked...

"Um, yeah. Could I also get three cinnamon buns, two pieces of strawberry cheesecake, and, uh, four muffin tops. To take home."

Alaina the barista charged Bella for the pastries and handed her the box. Bella almost ran across the store, and into the bathroom. Yes, she would share these with the roommates, of course, but...she needed to have just one or two muffin tops before resuming her date.

Her mouth was full of saliva and her stomach full of groaning as she locked the bathroom door. "Now!" she whispered to herself, in the mirror as she dug into the box, "now for a muffin...top...?"

Her hands froze in horror, as she caught sight of her midriff.

The jeans of the lovely blonde looking back at her were about to unsnap. They held her thighs and waist tightly like an ambitious seatbelt and over them spilled--yes, spilled--a perfectly tanned excess of flesh, folded in the middle.

"WHAT?" she screamed.

Was it a trick mirror? Couldn't be, those were FOLDS of flesh. How did that...she began to turn to survey the damage to her backside, when she caught a whiff of pastry from the box, and her belly shook with the growl of her stomach. A stream of drool burst from her mouth, and suddenly, she lost all control...

1511211.content:
Five minutes later, Bella raised her sticky, powdered face from the pastry box. "Oh...oh, God..." she said, dreamily, eyes still closed. She had always known she was beautiful. But now she really felt it. For the first time, she was tasting, digesting the beauty itself with which she was clothed. The warm glow sang inside of her, a tune of many colors, as stomach, heart and lungs provided rhythm and harmony. "Oh, wow..." She had never liked being full before. It had always made her feel uncomfortable. Now, it felt right. It all felt right, and beautiful, and she had a sense that, no matter what happened from here on out, everything in the world was right...everything was ordered, and surely, pleasure was at the center of the earth, of the universe, and nothing could ever...

Part of her brain woke up, and realized that the other part was babbling. It also realized that, every time she breathed in, harmonizing with the universe and what-not, she was hurting herself, somehow, as if there was a stitch in her side. She opened her eyes, and began to steady herself as she stood. Suddenly, she screamed, for someone's hand, on her right, reached past her, and touched the ground. She had locked the door. Had someone broken in? The barista, perhaps? But the hand was too plump to be Alaina's. She looked behind her, and screamed again, seeing no one. Someone must have come in, though, perhaps a meta-human with invisibility or teleportation, or...

"Is everything all right in there?" came the real barista's voice, from behind the door.

"Oh...fine..." called Bella, staggering to her feet. Her voice did not sound normal to her. It sounded....larger?

"Oh. My. God," said the voice, now, as emerald eyes opened wide with astonishment and a full, full mouth, caked with powdered sugar, hung open. Dimpled hands clasped full, round cheeks, which concealed any trace of once-austere cheekbones, and pulled at the chins that ran smoothly into a plump neck. In the mirror, the hands of the fat, surprised-looking blonde with the powdery face did the same.

"Oh. My. God," said Bella again, as the hands tremblingly continued their descent into hell, green eyes following. Abandon all hope, ye who enter...

The hands grabbed two overripe and floppy grapefruit, which pushed mercilessly against the inside of the tiny green shirt. The hands pulled them up, then let them drop again, against a belly which now hung entirely out of the shirt. The hands reached below the swollen gut to unfasten a pair of too-tight jeans, but realized, tremblingly, that they were too late. There was no button there any longer. It had flown off into some dingy corner of the bathroom while the think in the mirror was filling its mouth, grunting in ecstasy. The zipper had broken, as well. The hands traveled downward, downward, as the heart of the ringleted whale-maid in the mirror correspondingly sank. She thought of the Greek sailor in the next room, who could not now love her, ever. Everything--everything--had betrayed her. She did not turn to see her backside, but she could guess enough from the huge legs, which turned denim into spandex...

"A shape," the perfect pink tongue tapped against straight white teeth, barely above a whisper,"A shape with shapeless body and the head of a woman...A gaze blank and pitiless as the sun...Is moving its slow thighs, while all about... Oh God. What is that thing in there?"

With effort--it was suddenly so hard to move!--she stepped toward the heavy shape in the mirror, which, of course, did the same, its stupid face, which might have been beautiful in another age, still covered with powder. Bella bent down--as did the reflection, its belly folding into four neat ripples of golden flab--under the sink faucet, splashing her globular cheeks with water until sugar, honey, syrup, crumbs and makeup were washed out of her hair, out of every dimple, off every chin. Bella again looked at the image in the mirror.

"And what rough beast, its hour come round at last...Slouches towards Bethlehem to be born?"

The fat girl in the mirror ran her fingers through the mass of wet golden hair, cleared tears and water from a Bella's puffed cheeks and bright eyes, and answered herself, soberly.

"It's me."

There was a knock at the door. "Miss, are you all right?" Came the voice of Alaina.

Bella Hauge--Freya--the most beautiful superheroine in Paragon City, was halfway down the metro stairs, her curls halfway into a ponytail, her heart halfway into her mouth, when she realized she was being stupid, not heroic. She stopped on a landing between two flights of stairs, and looked up, out of the metro, to see if anyone was watching. Long, tanned legs pivoted on perfectly-arched feet, and a small, bright yellow butterfly of a dress floated out of the subway as its owner tossed her hair back around her shoulders.

Men stared and women glared at her as she walked back up Thomas Street, and she, as usual, ignored them.

"Hey, Freya!" bleated a woman's voice. She kept walking.

"Hey! Freya!" said the voice, more loudly than ever. "Aren't you supposed to be a superhero here?"

Freya turned around. The voice belonged to a plumpish woman just past her prime, holding the hand of a man who was--like every other man on the street--watching Freya's perfect figure without the slightest interest in anything else. The woman was dressed in a checkered black number, which was embarrassingly too tight, and she wore nice earrings.

"This isn't my type of thing," said Freya, dismissively. "Let the cops deal with it, or another superhero."

The woman let go of her awestruck husband's hand, and placed two balled-up hands on her sizeable hips. "So, Miss Freya--and that's a ridiculous name, by the way--"

"--It's Norse mythology--"

"Is it, now? You're very well educated, I can see, so maybe you can tell me WHY I pay taxes so that a little hussy posing as a superhero can prance around, giving my husband a hard-on when he was taking ME out for our ten-year anniversary?"

Oh, not this. Not again. She tried to keep her anger in check. She'd stopped feeling sorry for these petty older women a long time ago. It was hard enough not being able to talk to a man without every woman hating you for making them feel bad about themselves.

"I...uh...I did stop the Evil Dr. Rupert from taking control of the city several months ago, actually," she said, ending on a slightly aloof note.

"Oh, gee, I didn't hear about that on EVERY front page! 'Newsflash! Sluttiest, laziest superheroine actually foils one crime! Glad she finally did SOMETHING so we can use her little half-naked ass to sell more papers than Penthouse!' Stop LOOKING, Kevin!"

Poor bespectacled Kevin, to his credit, managed to flex a neck muscle, but his eyes remained glued on Bella's face.

His wife continued, "How did you manage to 'foil' the evil doctor's plan, anyway? Did he groan it all out into your ear while you moaned back like the whore you are?"

"What?" Bella's eyes smoldered.

How many of these criminals," she whispered, coolly now, "how many criminals are behind bars now, swapping stories about tearing off that little yellow dress? Maybe when they're not trying to break out of Guldhelm, they sketch maps of your cavernous--"

"You frumpy, old, dried out, FAT bitch!" screamed Bella. But the woman was clever. She couldn't win any battle of words (what was she going to say, other than calling names? 'Your dress is too tight'?), and she couldn't strike her, so she did the one thing she could think of. "Come here, Kevin!" she whispered seductively, and, drawing his poorly-shaven, pale chin towards hers, she kissed him, shoving her tongue into his mouth, where his lay, inert. Her hands began to roam, over his shoulders, down his back...and, suddenly, she realized with some embarrassment, she felt a little bit attracted to the paralyzed man.

"Get off my husband! Get off my husband! Get off my husband, you stupid slutcow! You get off him!"

WHAM!

The woman's plump fist landed a blow in Bella's taut stomach, causing her to pull out of Kevin's mouth, drawing out their mingled saliva in a string as she doubled over.

The woman kicked her face, bloodying her nose. "You stay away from him!" The woman shook with rage and heartbreak. "You stay away, f**k you, or I'll..."

Bella stood up and, making sure the woman saw her laugh--though she didn't feel like laughing--she continued to walk up Thomas Street. "Go buy a new dress that actually fits," she yelled, when she was a safe distance away. Hot tears came. I am pathetic, she thought, ashamed to death of feeling, momentarily, turned on by a middle-aged man. She wiped the blood from her nose with a bare fist, like a child. She was twenty-five. It had been her first kiss.

15121.content:
Her cell phone rang as she washed the blood off her hands and face. It had finally stopped five minutes before. She didn't recognize the number.

"Hello?"

"Hi." A man's voice on the other line. It sounded slightly nasal, but confident. "Is this Bella?"

"Who is this?" she asked, annoyed at the breach in phone protocol.

"This is Herman O'Lymp?" The voice sounded less confident now. Was there a hint of a foreign accent there as well?

"Who?"

"We, uh, e-mailed. You have the ad for a roommate on craigslist."

"Shit." She'd forgotten. He was going to come by today.

"I was just wondering if today was still fine for me to come see the place?"

"That's fine, but--"

"Great. I'm close by now, so I'll be right over. 432 Aiken, right?"

"Yes, but--"

"See you then!"

Great. She had never lived in the same house with a man before, and the prospect of someone gaping at her as she came out of the shower, did her laundry, or, hell, sat in sweatpants watching the History Channel, did not please her in the least. And what kind of a name was Herman O'Lymp?

"I'm not even going to be able to show him around," she suddenly thought. "He'll just freeze and goggle, like all these other men...shit..." She forgot this, sometimes, on the phone and the Internet, where she was able to talk to men as any other woman would--provided she didn't post her picture or tell them who she was. She had had a few Internet boyfriends--especially back in the days of dial-ups, when she was fourteen, and chat rooms seemed entirely novel. But every time--through e-harmony, match.com, craigslist--every time she met them in person, all the personality they'd shown just drained out of them, and they stared. "How can he find out anything?" She picked up her cell phone. "I'd better tell him to come back when Blur or Lantern are--"

The doorbell rang. Walking down the wooden hallway, she peered through the peephole (it was the only way, outside of TV, she could see what men were like before they saw her). She saw curly black hair and a mass of eyebrows, and a huge nose. Oh great. It was the ugly ones that were smitten the hardest, usually. She opened the door, noticing at once that he was not that ugly at all. She addressed him.

"Herman? I'm sorry, but you probably want to come back later. See, I have this power, and men can't usually talk with me easily. Anyway, you have a great day, and come back tomorrow, if you'd like, or I can interview you over the phone, if you'd prefer." There. Polite enough. But wait...the hairy man in front of her--who had, she noticed, finely sculpted features and lean muscles under a small, collared shirt and skinny jeans...had his mouth closed. In fact, he was even looking behind her, into the house. Then, he did something that no man, other than her father, had ever been able to do in her presence. He spoke.

"I, uh, think your nose is bleeding."

Now Bella gaped. "Um," she said. It wasn't the nosebleed that broke the spell of her face, she knew. She had tried all manner of disfigurements in the past, but they had either immediately healed, or made her look somehow more comely, if more pitiable. "You--you are talking to me..."

"Ah, yes. I do believe that it's important to speak, dear girl, particularly during an interview."

"Won't you come in," forgetting to make her voice rise at the end of the question. Now she was the one having trouble talking. Also, she realized he was actually not so ugly at all. And he had nice grey eyes. Sailor's eyes, she thought. Like in that song by Looking Glass. "No harbor was his home..."

They walked through the little house, and the man touched everything, straightening out magazines on the coffee table, smoothing out sheets on his prospective bed, walking up and down the stairs. "It's great. It's really great," he kept saying. He was attractive, all right, in an odd way, AND he was capable of actually talking to her--but he was annoying her, a bit.

"Why don't you sit down," she asked.

"Because you haven't offered yet," he smiled, his grey eye twinkling. The strange thing was that though he was incredibly fidgety, he was possessed of an extraordinary cockiness and confidence that threw her off-guard. Not that she needed much to throw her off-guard. A man was TALKING to her! Looking at her, breathing in the pheromones she apparently sent out, and talking to her like she was no one special. She was suddenly aware of her own heartbeat. But perhaps she could throw HIM off, as well.

"So," she began, "you possess a speed-related power of some kind?"

"And you," he answered, "possess keen powers of perception behind all that beauty."

She had no idea how to respond to this. Was he trying to charm her? "Uhhh, thanks."

"How did you know?"

"You're very fidgety. And you got here so...fast. Do you have...any other powers?"

"I never said you were right about speed, and now we're on to other powers? How do you know I have any powers at all?"

Because you can TALK to me without drooling, she thought, but what she said was, "Ordinary men don't typically volunteer to live with meta-women. It feels...emasculating."

"Ah," said Herman. "Yes, I suppose it must be, for them."

"Aha!" said Bella, triumphantly. "See, you ARE a meta-human."

"I am NOT," shot back Herman, sounding...insulted?

"And you're fine with moving here, even though you might feel...emasculated."

"Ah," said Herman, a bit excitedly. "Now we come to it."

"Come to what?" She was feeling a little exasperated, now. Was this what all men acted like, in person?

"You haven't offered me anything to drink. Where I come from, that's bad manners."

"Where I come from," she rejoined, rising from the table, and opening the fridge, "it's bad manners to point out someone else's bad manners. We have milk, water, and diet grape."

"Diet grape? Are you kidding?"

"Afraid not." Francesca--Lantern--had a sweet tooth, but also a two-piece picked out for her upcoming honeymoon. Magnets had been fastened to the fridge, holding pictures of models with her Sicillian roommate's face glued onto them.

"Sure," guffawed the man, seeming very sailorly indeed. "If you have no wine, diet grape will have to do."

Who did this Herman O'Lymp think he was? She poured a glass for him--and one for her, lest he be under the delusion that she was used to serving men--and sat down.

"So," she began, "you were saying?"

He looked uncomfortable for the first time. "I was saying," he began, "that I did not actually come to see the house. I came to see you."

She had always been able to feel it when she blushed, but never like this. At first, she felt extremely pleased, if terribly embarrassed. Next, she realized that this might not be an ideal situation. Here was a strange man who had her, alone, in her house, and she, apparently, had no power over him. She began to think about where in the house the knife was.

"See," Herman began, taking a sip of diet grape, and then grimacing, "As I was saying, I am no meta-human. But I am also no human." He took another sip. "Kinda grows on you, I'll admit. Anyway, I am a god."

Oh great, thought Bella. I've been falling for a crazy man who is about to rape or kill me.

"And I didn't come here," said Herman, "about your house." He waved his hand, dismissively. "I came for you, because YOU, Bella, are a god as well."

She rose, walking across the kitchen slowly, to where the knives were.

"Think, Bella," continued Herman O'Lymp, his mediterranean brow looking like a cloudy sky just before lightning. "Think about it. You know you never made a very good human, OR a very good metahuman. Your place is with us, with the gods. I was sent to find you."

She backed against a drawer, which she slid open, quietly, just like the desperate women in the movies did.

He stood up and walked toward her. "Why do you think your powers don't work on me? Because they're the same kind as the ones I have. Not mere powers, but divinity! God does not impress god, for we are higher beings than these...mortals (he gestured toward the picture-laden refrigerator). You ought to come with me. You ought to join us."

"You...uh...probably ought to leave." Bella's groping hand latched onto a knife handle behind her.

Herman suddenly seemed very tall, but he smiled, brilliantly, boyishly, his black brows lifting under his curls. "Very well," he said. "But if you change your mind, you have my e-mail. Really, you can reach me however you'd like. I am The Messenger." Then suddenly, it was as though he jumped onto the air itself. His body, starting from his feet and head, glowed silver, and he began to run on an unseen floor--then suddenly, vanished with a blinding flash and deafening clap of thunder.

By the time Bella whipped out the knife, there was nothing to be seen of the man, but as she listened to the thunderclap echo in her head, she thought she heard the nasal voice say, with a laugh, "And you are The Mother."

She stood for a moment, speechless, trying to think of something to say that would ease the bizarre atmosphere created in her mind by the whole thing. The best she could come up with was, "Showoff," as she took a casual sip of his disgusting diet grape soda.

Then she stopped. "The MOTHER?" she repeated. "Ugh." She drained the glass.

Suddenly, her phone rang. The display read, "Flyboy."

"Hello?"

"Hey, is this Freya?" asked a somewhat panicked voice. There was shouting in the background.

"Sure is, Flyboy. What's going on?"

"I think you'd better come down to the metro station. Bring your roommates. We have a...um...situation here."

"They're--" Flyboy hung up.

"Great," said Bella.
