151211.content:
Kevin cleared his throat and turned to his seething wife in the checkered skirt (who was named Janet).

"Still want to see a movie?" His voice cracked, slightly. He had been incapable of speech and movement for about ten minutes after that meta-woman--Freya--had kissed him. What an anniversary.

His wife gave him a look. "What do YOU think?" she said, icily.

"Jan, come on, it wasn't my fault." He took her hands in his, beginning to massage them with his thumbs, which ordinarily she liked. She pulled her hands away.

"Yeah, I'm sure you didn't enjoy THAT at all."

"I didn't!" he lied. "You know she hypnotizes people."

"Men. She hypnotizes weak little men. Thanks for dinner, Kevin. Let's go home." She started to walk toward the metro, forgetting the explosion and smoke that had issued from it only twenty minutes before.

That hurt, thought Kevin. I hate it when she calls me by my name like that. And I really tried. Took her to a five-star, expensive restaurant, and watched her gorge herself with food and cake. She's been overeating ever since we found out she couldn't have kids, but insisting on continuing to wear her old clothes, so that I'm half-embarrassed every time we go out. But still, still I don't want to be with anyone else. Have I said a word about her eating? About her general bitchiness? Despite all that, SHE'S the one, always has been. "Some guys," he began, catching up with her, as she started down the stairs, "don't even remember their wives' birthdays or anniversaries. Have I EVER missed ONE?"

She stopped, halfway down the metro stairs. The pasta, still tossing in her stomach, made her feel increasingly uncomfortable and irritable. "Don't you think," she said, "I would rather you'd missed it than kissed another woman?" Great, she thought. Tears were now visible in her eyes, which made her vulnerable to 'comforting.'

"Honey..." he tried to take her hands again. But at that moment, they heard a strange, unearthly hiss in the metro below.

"My God, we're stupid," exclaimed Janet. "We can't use this metro, remember? We were so distracted by that little bitch that it almost killed us."

"Janet, I'm sorry," said Kevin. Sex, he supposed, was out of the question tonight, but it hurt him to see those tears in her eyes. She was a good woman.

"We'll talk about--" Janet began. But just as they began to turn to walk up the stairs, there was a blinding flash of light, and Janet fell forward.

"Jan!" called Kevin, and caught her.

She leaned on him. "Lightning from the metro?" she grunted.

"Probably another explosion. Come on, let's take a cab."

"I think...Kevin, I think something hit me. I feel REALLY strange."

"Let's get to a bench and sit down then. I'll have a look at you." He tried--and succeeded--to sound manly, and in-control. He wasn't extremely worried. He'd seen nothing hit her, just that flash of light below."

But he became a little more worried when, as she leaned on him, he noticed she was having more and more trouble walking. In addition, the amount of her weight that he was supporting increased. By the time they reached the top of the metro stairs, he could barely hold her up. He dragged her to the nearest bench, and took out his phone to call an ambulance.

"Honey...no..." Janet protested. "I'll be..." Suddenly, doubled over on the park bench. He sat next to her, holding tightly to her hand, while he called 9-1-1 with the other hand.

He gave their location information quite calmly, watching his wife the entire time. Her hand felt odd--swollen, in fact. "Jan, are you okay?" he asked. "Is the pain bad?"

"No pain..." gasped Janet, trying to sit up... "it's just all very strange-feeling, she said, looking down." That was when Kevin noticed something odd, as well. His wife's already-round face was swelling as well--but it didn't look like the kind of swelling you got from a bee-sting. It wasn't red or puffy, just...bigger? Her dark eyes, wide-open in an expression of horror, began to look smaller and smaller behind ripening cheeks. Her lips thickened, and below that, her chin and neck disappeared in folds of flesh. She had been gaining weight, it was true, but now it was as if someone had hit fast-forward. He heard the waistband of her checkered skirt snap, and it was as though a dam had burst. Waves of pasty, white flesh overflowed her clothing, leaving only black and checkered wreckage in their wake. He took off his jacket to cover her, and phoned the ambulance again.

"...some kind of allergic reaction..." Janet had heard her husband say, before passing out entirely.

When she came to, she felt hands on her wrist, checking her pulse. To her surprise, she did not feel sick or injured. She started to say, "I'm okay, but the paramedic shushed her, pushing her fingers deep into Janet's now-fleshy wrist. "Your husband, I'm afraid, has also gone into shock," said the paramedic in a matter-of-fact tone of voice. She was a cute little redhead, and Janet felt the normal surge of jealousy, which was exacerbated all the more by her present condition.

"Just hang on, miss, and we'll try to get this stretcher under you, and...and..." Janet now saw a change in the paramedic's expression. "Guys, I feel really weird," said the girl. She was beginning to look a bit weird, thought Janet. Her petite, 22-year-old body, Janet noticed, was beginning to expand as well, and now her belly and boobs grew more pronounced within the constraints of the EMT uniform, until they seemed to hang over Janet. The paramedic's hands went from Janet's wrist, up to her own face, and she shrieked. "OH MY GOD!" as she felt new folds of flesh growing, multiplying. Janet stood up, with some difficulty, and tried to offer the paramedic her hand. "You keep away from me!" screamed the EMT, rolling on the ground.

Janet ran to another paramedic, and pulled her, by the hand, toward her colleague. But when she turned around she saw that this girl, as well, was now having trouble walking on now-plump legs. "I'm contagious," she whispered. "Oh my God. I'm contagious."

She fell to her knees, looking up into the sky, still clutching Kevin's coat around her 300-pound body. And then she caught sight of a figure in the sky. "Help!" she shouted. "Help us!"

A lithe young man, immediately, alighted on the park bench where Janet herself had doubled her body mass. "What's wrong, ma'am?"

"We...need...help..." shouted the first paramedic.

Flyboy, a novice, at nineteen, couldn't think of what to do. So he telephoned the senior superheroes who lived closest to Thomas Street. First, Lantern. Voicemail. Blur? Voicemail. Freya? Aha.

Freya's long, shapely legs pushed her down the street as fast as they could, and she was at the metro about ten minutes later, where she saw about five or so, very large women writhing on the pavement--one a policewoman, who had outgrown her unflattering uniform, one dressed in a tiny waitress outfit, two paramedics--and one! One looked a lot like that woman--Kevin's wife--except--no, she had certainly not been that big! Bella ran to Flyboy, who hovered above the mess. "What's going--?"

"YOU!" growled the black-haired woman, rising, half-nude and half checkered and coat-covered.

Before Bella could reply, she found herself in a sweaty, smelly, fleshy embrace with her former rival, her tiny body nearly enveloped by the mass of the other. She tried to shake Janet loose, but the older woman clung to her until, Bella noticed, the tension between their two bodies grew. Bella felt, horrified, her own breasts, her own stomach, arms and thighs, growing, pushing back against her rival's. At last, she managed to throw Janet off of her entirely. She could not catch her breath. She struggled with the back of her dress, attempting to undo it before it choked her. As she did, she felt it rip behind her. Her bra was already broken. She looked down in horror, at a massive tummy, gargantuan breasts, and huge thighs, which shed the broken yellow dress like a snakeskin. Looking back up at Kevin's wife, she noticed a somewhat satisfied smile on her fat face.

"Well," said Janet. "At least SOMETHING good happened today. I daresay, you're even fatter than I am now, you slutty little manatee."

Bella buried her face in her hands. This couldn't be happening.

"What?" Came the scornful voice. "Fat little Freya isn't crying, is she?"

Freya heard Flyboy, above her. "Freya, listen, I was trying to tell you--whatever this is, it's very, very contagious. Now that you've been infected, you need to stay here, and don't touch anyone. Everyone stay where you are," he repeated, to them all.

Of course, a few of them didn't listen. But Freya was among the fifteen-or-so ample-bodied women, who, three hours later, boarded an emergency vehicle, and were driven away, to a special infirmary floor on Guldhelm which had been cleared, temporarily, for the obese, hysterical, and very contagious, women.

1512111.content:
Bella turned over on her now-massive side, clutching her pillow over her head to drown out the sounds, all around her, of uncontrollable sobbing, fighting and snoring. She wanted so badly to sleep--to be lost in oblivion, rather than in the padded room with white sheets and cots and huge crying women. It reminded her of that horrific scene in Pinnochio, where the boys turned into donkeys and were trapped on Pleasure Island. She was ravenously hungry, but, even more than that, thirsty. There was no water in the huge room. She envied the women who had not listened to Flyboy and the police, even if they WERE contagious. Here, they were being treated like animals, she thought.

Every time she started to drift off, she heard the doors clang open and shut, and another sobbing woman or two--dressed, presumably in the oversized blue hospital gowns that all of them had on--would find space for her bedroll, and lie down as male guards gave orders. She was surprised that she felt sorry for them. She had been the really beautiful one. She was the one to be most pitied, who had lost the most, wasn't she? She started to resent them, then realized that, even before today, she was comfortable being a freak. Beautiful freak or disgusting freak, what did it matter? She did miss her roommates, but these women had husbands and lovers and careers that they were mourning.

She heard a little scream on the other end of her unit, accompanied by the sound of flesh being kicked and punched. The scream rose to a wail, then was suddenly cut off. "That will shut you up, you ugly cow! It was YOU who did this to us! Don't think we don't know that! YOU ruined our lives!" The thudding of a foot connecting with flesh, and Bella could hear the woman whimper, "Kevin...Kevin...I want my Kevin, where..." Another thud, and then silence.

Bella smiled, turned over on her back again, and fell asleep.

"...a few small protests being held outside of Guldhelm," stated the reporter on television, "but most do understand that this is a temporary situation--a precaution against additional women becoming morbidly obese, as we try to understand the nature of the epidemic..."

Skinny little bitch, thought Bella. I'd like to get a hold of her and teach her to talk so coolly about the situation. See if she still has that reporter job when she's a size thirty. This thought was echoed aloud by a number of the infirmary inmates. Lights had come on at approximately 8:00 AM, and guards--with clubs, for goodness sake! As if they were dangerous criminals!--had pushed out several carts of airplane-esque food and water, which the women--there were about forty of them now, Bella guessed--pushed and shoved to get to. As they tore open the cartons, bypassing the plastic cutlery and literally shoving the food into their ravenous mouths, one of the senior guards repeated that the government did apologize for this measure, that it was only temporary, that the blue-clad inmates were free to watch television. He was also making every effort to ensure that books would be brought up later today, and possibly a few computers to allow for Internet time. They were also, he said, somewhat embarrassedly, looking into getting exercise equipment. The women--they had been lawyers, housewives, doctors, nurses, waitresses--even, Bella recognized, one or two superheroines--made no reply--each, to a woman, was devouring her food. Bella did not remember, five minutes later, what the food had been. She took a long drink of water.

"Oh my God!" came a voice, close by. "It's happening, again! Why is it happening again?" Bella watched as the billowy robes became a little tighter around each woman's body, including her own. Her paunch and breasts protruded further than ever, and she screamed as well.

One woman--a doctor, Bella thought--stood up, her form still expanding. "Stop eating the food!" she cried. "Somehow our bodies aren't digesting it right. Everyone stop eating!" She was far too late, Bella thought.

They were all still hungry, and even moreso by lunchtime, but they didn't dare partake when the guards brought them their midday portions. Bella clutched her gut--oh, it felt SO empty!--and attempted to distract herself with the news.

"How many people are infected?" queried the hated anchor, to some doctor or other.

"It's hard to say," said the man, a clean-cut Hispanic official of some kind--probably of the State Department or Health Board. "Right now, I'm hearing hundreds, at least. Paragon City is doing everything it can to prevent its spread to other parts of the United States and the globe. Police--male police, as they seem to be immune to the effects, and superhero units--are busy rounding up everyone they can. This is proving especially difficult in the case of female meta-humans who have caught it, but slowly we are..."

There was a bit of laughter and shouting coming from a crowd of women who were gathered in the corner, Bella noticed. Around someone, or something, it seemed. She decided to investigate, and wedged her substantial behind between other heavy, standing figures who were shouting, "Eat, eat, eat!" Kevin's black-haired wife, slumped on the floor, was struggling frantically, her fat arms flailing, her mouth being held open by two of the other women, who also kept back her disheveled mass of black curls. Bella realized with horror--but also, she admitted, gratification--that they had already force-fed the poor woman about five of the dinners.

One of the ringleaders, a girl with red hair, who might have been the paramedic Bella saw yesterday--was shouting down at her. "That's right, eat, you pig! You know how every classroom needs a fat kid to pick on? We've nominated YOU to be ours!"

"I--I'm s-s-sorr--" Janet tried to say, but her mouth was forced open again, as a sixth dinner was forced into her mouth. "From now on," continued the redhead, "you're going to be this class's pet pig. You deserve it, for making us like this. Look," she said, picking up a brownie," the guards left us some dessert as well. Would you like some, pig? Say oink!" Hot tears poured over Janet's monstrous cheeks. Bella could see every fold of the poor woman's flesh behind the gown.

"Please...please stop..." begged Janet.

"We'll stop," said the paramedic. "We'll stop, but SINCE you're the pet pig, I want you to say oink for us. Give us a real piggy snort, and we'll think about stopping."

"I'm sorr--"

"Not good enough! Snort, piggy, or we keep stuffing this in your greedy little mouth."

Janet snorted, sobbed, and snorted again. It was, Bella thought, a fairly good imitation of a pig. The women holding Janet erupted in laughter.

"Now, piggy, I don't want to see you walking around on your hind legs, the way we humans can. Do you hear me? A piggy as fat as you needs all four legs to trot around on."

"Pl-please..." begged Janet. "Please, I didn't mean..."

"Hands and knees!" shouted another girl, a brunette with darkish skin, who looked familiar to Bella. Had she been a celebrity of some kind? Janet complied.

"The piggy shouldn't wear human clothes," said the Indian girl.

"I--" began Janet.

"I think she wants some more!" laughed the redhead, sadistically. Bella was shocked to feel some pity for the woman who was responsible for her present condition--as well as some envy, she realized, that she was getting so much food. The women held Janet's head back, and forced two brownies into Janet's mouth. Then they ripped the gown off of her as her form exploded yet again.

"Now, trot away, piggy," laughed the Indian girl. "Trot away, and we'd better hear you grunt like a happy little piggy, or we'll think you're hungry for some more."

The humiliated, naked woman oinked loudly for the women's amusement and scrambled away on all fours, her bloated belly and breasts nearly scraping the ground, her bottom and legs two quivering crests of flesh. Bella looked at her tormentors, suddenly feeling that they were not so fat after all. Neither was she. It was that pig, Janet, in the corner. She was the fat one. Nevertheless, though it made her feel better about herself, another part of her realized that they were all behaving like animals. If this behavior went unchecked, she could be the next one who was picked on. This place could be hell.

The television interrupted her reverie. "...also received word that meta-woman and superheroine Bella Hauge, also known as Freya, is among those who have been interned at..."

"Hey," said the brown-haired Indian girl. Bella ignored her.

"Hey," she repeated. "I THOUGHT that was you! So, not so special now, are you?"

"Neither are you, apparently," retorted Bella to the former model-actress. She recognized her now, as Rubiana Kumar, formerly of Bollywood. "Not that you ever were, over here."

Oooh. Burned. But that was pretty stupid, as well, Bella thought. Rubiana seemed to enjoy quite a following in the infirmary, at least. Rubiana did not show the slightest sign of anger. Instead she cocked her head to the side, gestured toward a few of the other girls, and said, simply, "You look hungry. Our poor pig over there IS lonely." Bella stood up at once, to fight, but was at once held down by the paramedic and the policewoman. She screamed, but immediately food was shoved into her mouth. God, but it was good. And she was hungry. One mouthful wouldn't hurt...

"Oh, don't do THAT, Rubiana," scoffed the red-head. "She's so BEAU-tiful, with her perfect curls and dark eyes, and golden skin...do you really want to ruin her beauty EVEN MORE?"

"I don't know what you're talking about, Roberta," retorted Rubiana, making Bella swallow another mouthful, rubbing it all over her face. "If her skin is so beautiful, shouldn't there be more of it...for everyone to see? Piggy over there is so pasty, but this one...I think this one deserves THE REST of the food."

Yes! cried Bella's stomach. "No!" screamed her food-filled mouth.

Then, past the smiling fat faces, she heard another, "NO! You get the HELL off her, lard-ass!" At once, Rubiana and Roberta were simultaneously flung across the infirmary by a familiar, if pudgy, bright-white hand. The rest of the girls moved aside.

"Bella! Sweet Bella!" came a familiar voice, now more husky than she remembered it. "Are you okay, my lovely darling? I'm so sorry, Bella, that the epidemic hit you! Oh, sweetie, you look terrible."

Bella spat out a mouthful of casserole. "Francesca! Lantern! You're here too?"

"That's right, hon." Did she glow brighter now that there was more of her? "But it's okay. Guess I'll have to find a new wedding-dress, though," she chirped. "And forget all that nonsense about the two-piece." She clasped her hand over her belly and jiggled it, and for a moment--only a moment--a serious look came over her face. Then, she laughed, and the light grew brighter. "Oh, Francesca, but I'm really sorry about you. It's worse when someone as perfect-looking as you...well, anyway." The Sicillian meta-human, despite being 5'2" and (now) approximately 230 pounds, stood up tall and proud, and raised her voice.

"Attencion! Everyone!" she cried, shrilly. "As of now, and until further notice, I, Lantern, am taking control of this floor. The women shielded their eyes, unable to look directly at the bioluminescent energy shining from within Lantern's hospital gown. They could barely, at this point, make out a face. "You will leave each other alone! No more force-feeding. And the two of you!" she turned to Rubiana and Roberta. "You will take off your gowns. You will give them to Janet, over there, and you will be cold and naked until the guards come back with some extra supplies tonight! Shame on you!" Rubiana opened her mouth to say something, but hid her eyes and cowered, as Lantern grew even brighter.

She really is a marvel, thought Bella enviously and gratefully. Most of all, she felt relief that she now had her friend with her. But this was Lantern. And that was a problem. With her in charge, things in the infirmary would still be unpredictable. She only needed wait a few hours.

The guards, at dinnertime, wheeled in a few computers, along with foods that they said, according to tests conducted on other infected women, did not produce further weight gain. The women took them at their word, and devoured the soy-tasting morsels. "You will eat the food with cutlery, not like animals!" cried Lantern, still sounding cheerful enough. But Bella noticed Francesca's light was on the wane.

By the time they were checking their mail, sitting next to one another, there was no glow at all, and Bella could perfectly make out Francesca's tanned, greasy skin, and the shadow of the moustache across her lip that she usually so painstakingly plucked, along with her eyebrows. Her hair no longer glowed white, but was her usual glossy light brown. This was not good. The girl had used up too much energy taking charge. A thought came to her, and she found, in her list of e-mail addresses, one hermanolymp@gmail.com. She typed, "Help us, please," into the message body, and clicked send. Then she looked back at Francesca, who had just finished writing to her fiance, Jack Sawyer--that metahuman clown who called himself Jigsaw. Francesca turned back to her, and said, quietly, clutching her hand, "Bella...Oh, Bella, I don't want him to see me like this. I want to stay here. I'm so, so afraid he won't love me anymore." Bella noticed the air around Francesca beginning to darken. Ladies and...ladies, she thought, I present to you Lantern, the one and only bi-polar superheroine... And she was in charge.

Things got hard after Internet time. Lantern began, slowly, to withdraw, her expression to cloud, and by nightfall, Bella could no longer see the girl distinctly--she was blue-black skin in a dark corner that she took wherever she went. And she was sobbing to Bella, saying, "So fat. I'm so fat. Jack said he loves me, but...who could love someone who looks like this?" Some of the girls, thinking their activities now beyond Lantern's awareness, took the opportunity to pinch Janet's fleshy stomach, whispering "Piggy, piggy, piggy," into her ear. Janet, who had become a little more like her old fiery self since being stood up for, pinched back. Seeing this, red-headed Roberta produced a few brownies, leftover from lunch, and brandished them in Janet's direction. Janet, horrified, cried out a little.

Suddenly, Roberta could no longer see Janet at all. She could not see anything, beyond two eyes that glowed like demons' eyes from a jet-black female form. "Good," said an ice-cold voice, quite different from the earlier Lantern's, "You have a brownie, I see. Go ahead and eat it, I don't mind." Roberta turned pale, and attempted to put the brownie away. "EAT IT," came the voice, again. Roberta obediently took one bite, then another, until the food disappeared, and her body trembled, growing a little.

"Good girl," said Lantern, clutching Roberta's arm with her indigo hand.

"Aieeee!" screamed Roberta. "You're burning me! You're hurting me!"

"I don't care," said Lantern, wearily, and proceeded to leech energy from the girl's plump body, until it fell over.

"Is she dead?" asked Bella, when Lantern had resumed her place by her side.

"I don't know and I don't care," said Lantern. The effort had taxed her, greatly, but Bella knew that the energy she had taken from the girl would make her all the brighter and more powerful when her mood changed again. She hoped Herman, or the Messenger, or whatever he was, had gotten her message.

She drifted off, holding the dark, cold hand of the Sicilian bride-to-be beside her, as the latter cried herself to sleep.

She was awakened by her own snoring, and she sat up. Then, suddenly, there was a man before her, not three inches from her face. His powerful hand covered her mouth as she instinctively shrieked.

"Not a word," he breathed into her ear. "You stand up and come with me."

"But what about..." she began.

"Listen, fatso"--the white teeth grinned, sadistically--"do you want out, or not? The rest of them are not important. They are not like us."

"But I can't leave France--can't leave my fr--," Suddenly, Bella was aware that the long, lean--but surprisingly strong--arms were holding her against a body which smelled of olives and the sea. Herman O'Lymp, or The Messenger, or Mercury, or whoever he was, pressed his mouth against hers, clutching her to his heartbeat, massaging her arms, and sides, and--

"I--" she began, but was interrupted a second time, by alien lips and teeth, as, wrapping her flabby arms around his neck--who knew when this would ever happen again?--she kissed him with all her might. And in that moment, despite her circumstance, she was a goddess.

The embrace ended, and she, woozily, let Herman lead her toward the barred doors. He snapped his fingers, and they opened at once, without so much as a clang. The snores of the other women echoed across the room, and she tried, again, to ask for mercy for her friend.

"Bella," he whispered again, fiercely, into her ear, "tonight is YOUR night. Tonight is the night you come into your destiny. It is not Francesca's night. You must let her go. Besides, she is doing too much good here."

Bella conceded that this might be the case, but could she really abandon her friend? She looked at the door, which stood open. Herman fidgeted, impatiently, with her hair.

15121112.content:
Eight A.M. Lights on. I turn over, to see Francesca there, on the next bedroll. My lips twitch, thirstily, remembering Herman's sweet kiss of the night before. I hug my huge body, remembering leaner, stronger arms. He had looked so sad. Heartbroken, in fact, when I said I couldn't go. I have no clue why--with this body of mine, why!--he would even want me. But he clearly did. No other man or meta-man would....perhaps he was a god...

"Fine," he had whispered, slightly angrily, there at the door. "But I cannot come for you again. Not here. The Messenger comes only once, to the same person, in the same place, with the same message. If she doesn't respond, well...that's her lookout."

I'd kissed him again--boldly--there in the dark. "Herman, you have to believe that I want to. But I can't just turn my back on my friend...not after she helped me."

"So you turn your back on me, instead, when I want to help you?" he had said again, almost choking on a sob, I realized! "When I tell you that I love you? Fine. You have your human rules, but I have mine, too. I won't be back."

"Herman, wait," I had called, but he was behind the barred door already, shaking his head, and it was closed. "Oh, Bella, Bella, thwarter of my love and your destiny," he'd said. "Don't you know I'm too impatient to wait?"

"Kiss m--" I'd started to say, desperately, but he had vanished.

Now, lying here on the cot, looking across at Francesca, glowing and smiling slightly, in her sleep, I know I did the right thing. My heart, though, feels even bigger and emptier than my gut. Ugh.

Francesca opens her eyes. "Good morning, dear roommate," she beams. "I'm so glad you're here." I grab her plump, hand, glittering with light, and smile as convincingly as possible.

"And I'm glad to be with you," I say.

***

Showers! Thank God. We stink. It's bad enough that fat people are condemned to look like this. But we have to smell, too.

We're taken, in groups of ten, to the showers. Francesca goes with the second group, and she comes back, radiant, her brown Sicilian hair in a towel, her moist, glowing skin causing rainbows to spread over her thick arms and legs. "It's wonderful," she says, drying off her hair. "I didn't expect hot water!"

"Group three!" shouts the guard at the door. "Rubiana Kumar, Bella Hauge, Janet Howard, Grace Henderson, Juana Jarvis, Roberta Arlington..."

Great. Grouped in with three of my favorite people. I line up behind poor, massive Janet, fatter and shorter than any of us, who glares at me, but who also looks pretty apprehensive about being in a shower with the bullies.

"I hope they don't use these groups every day," I whisper to her, attempting to make peace.

"Hope not," she echoes. But her tone is a little softer.

***

I'm drying off. God, there's so much more to dry, now, and our towels are less than twice the size of a washcloth. I glance over at Janet, who is having twice the difficulty of any of us. As it turns out, we didn't need to worry about Rubiana and Roberta, after all. When we arrived at the shower room, filing past where the guards were allowed, we noticed the two of them whispering something to one of the guards. They were both smiling in a very...contrived way. Then, the guards closed the doors to the shower room, but just before they did, I saw Roberta's hand touch the guards face in an...indiscreet...way. The two of them never rejoined us. I have a fleeting, ridiculous thought that they are trading favors in order to get better showers. That's stupid, I think. Anyway, who would want them? But then...Herman wanted me, I suppose. I reach toward the dispenser. There's no proper deoderant in the place, but there is some powder, at least, that I can shove up under my deep armpit. Hell, I should apply it everywhere, in fact. All kinds of...pits end up stinking on this body. I think, not for the first or the last time, that there has to be a way out--of this prison--and more importantly, of this body. But it's likely that the only way out of this body is through this prison. Could there have been another motive to my staying, besides pure loyalty? The scientists must be coming up with something, even now.

***

Breakfast. I sit at one of the fold-out tables they've now brought up--next to France', as always. She is talking excitedly.

"Bella, the scientists have--the guards told me, while you were at shower, that the scientists believe they can cure this, at least in metahumans. They think they can help me--can help us!" she laughed, her mouth full of the bland, wafery stuff that doesn't cause us to gain weight. We eat it, morning, noon and night, and I wouldn't take another bite if I wasn't so hungry!

"That's wonderful," I manage through my own mouthful, hope soaring.

"I know!" she beams, literally. "They're going to bring me to the doctor in about an hour, they said. I might get to keep that wedding dress and two-piece, after all!"

I hear a laugh from a few tables over. Rubiana and Roberta are talking loudly. I'm not sure about what. They seem more careless than they have for the past day or so. They had returned, just before ten o' clock breakfast, looking clean and fairly pleased with themselves--touching the arms of the guards who escorted them. This could be a problem, I think.

***
1:00 PM. I choke down lunch by myself. I haven't seen France' since she left at 10:45, light radiating from her face, as Rubiana and Roberta snickered. I hope she's okay.

***

6:00 PM. More white stuff for dinner. I'm sitting alone, again, growing more and more worried about France'. Did they just cure her and let her go? Did she forget, in her manic state, to tell them about me--that I'm a meta-human? Or was, anyway. God, I used to be so, so beautiful. Herman, my love, I miss you. Please take me away, if you can hear me.

"Is BlubberGirl blubbering?" asks a rude voice, tinged with an Indian accent, next to me.

"Oh, can it, Rubi," I say. "I don't want trouble."

"Oh, I just bet you don't," laughs Roberta, next to her. "I just bet you don't, now that your GIRLFRIEND isn't here to save your lard ass."

"You're fatter than me, Roberta," I laugh, but I'm a little nervous, now.

"We'll soon fix that, won't we, Rubi?" asks Roberta. "We have friends now, on the outside," she said. "And these friends are so wonderfully helpful. Not only did they help your poor friend Lantern get out of here, no questions asked, just like that...but we also told them about how HUNGRY you were, and they gave us some real food to feed our new favorite prize Pig.

I stand up, alarmed. "You fat-assed, whoring..."

"Sit down!" she shouts, and then, to my horror, I see a few of the girls, chuckling, as a bucket of what looks like pancake batter is brought in my direction.

"Piggy Number One!" Rubiana calls to Janet, "I want you to come here and slop our NEW piggy for us. Janet, to her credit, looks defiant, though only for a moment. "Piggy Number One...you'd better come here, NOW, because this slop has to be eaten by SOMEONE. Janet's eyes glance mournfully down at her wrecked form--any more, and she'll die--and she strides, thighs rubbing, to where I am.

There is no point in fighting. I am surrounded by at least ten girls, each of them afraid of being the next victim. France', Herman...someone...help.

Janet scoops a cup of batter out of the bucket, and her eyes glisten with hatred. Fear has made her crueler. "Well, well. Bella Hauge, the Belly Hog. Say 'Oink!' I'll teach you to kiss my Kevin, you corpulent whore!" The rest of the girls laugh, holding my arms, as I choke on the thick stuff. Perhaps I can struggle free, for now. But is there a point?

151211122.content:
Breakfast over. I crawl into Corner, now, and wait for Lunchtime. Hurts to crawl, these days, the way everything drags against the cold floor--the awful sores on me underside! Sometimes, me knee trods on belly, and then I squeal in pain! Saw doctor a few months ago, and he says, "You can't eat so much." Can't eat so much! I laughed, quivering, snorting. He shouldn't say things like that. Oh, what would I do without me food--the delicious slop that I get three times a day! After all, me name is Belly Hog.

I no like the name at first, when the Skinnygirls give it to me. But now I see that it fits! It fits so well, for, you see, I have great belly, and love to eat, like a hog! How I used to hate them, every Mealtime! Hate THEM, the ones who were so generous, giving me all the Slop I wanted! But after about a month, when me body get too big for any of the clothes, and I MUST to trot around without them, I no fight at all. And now, some of the Skinnygirls I hated most...well, they are the best to me. Example, Rubiana, sometimes comes to me corner, when I'm lying there, waiting for nextmeal, and she pats me on my enormous, naked behind. "Good hog," she says. "That's a good Belly Hog. Dinner will be here, soon, don't worry." If I had a tail, like other hogs do, I would wag it. But as it is, I snort and grunt back at her, as happy as I can. I don't remember how to talk. At least, I don't think I could if I tried. I snort and grunt, though, and most understand, "Belly Hog has to go to the bathroom," or "Belly Hog is hungry!" Or, "Look how happy Belly Hog is!"

*FIN*
151211122.title: Bella does not fight back.

151212.content:
Bella sat, angrily, on the sofa, crossed her bare arms, agitatedly, and felt sorry for herself.

Some superhero I am, she thought. Kevin's wife was right. I've got to have the most absurd power...

Well, that wasn't strictly true. There had been a metahuman at the Academy who was able to produce radioactive mucus at will. That was more ridiculous. Not to mention disgusting. But still. When she couldn't answer a call about problems at the metro because she knew a male superhero would be there...that was stupid. Maybe that Messenger had something, after all, with his whole, 'You're not like them,' line. Maybe, on the other hand, he was a freakish exception to the way her power interacted with males, and he was using that line to get into her pants.

"And that's a BAD thing?" she said out loud, suddenly covering her mouth. Yeah, she wasn't going to be easy...maybe Kevin's wife was right about that, too. She thought about Herman's smile. Then she stood up, and went to her room, where her ancient laptop hummed at her desk. Here goes, she thought, or something equally cliche.

To: hermanolymp@gmail.com
Subject: Re: your message

Text: Herman,
No idea who or what you are, but I _would_ like a better idea of what I am. Would appreciate if you would meet me so we can talk further about whatever opportunity. Call or something. I don't know. Talk to you later.

(She hesitated a moment, her perfect face blushing beneath the golden tan)

Love (backspace) Sincerely (backspace) Yours truly,

Bella/Freya

And, closing her eyes tightly, she hit "send."

She walked back to the living room, plopped back into the couch, and turned on the television.

The screen flashed, and then, suddenly, a silver humanoid form leapt out of it, across the living room, and on top of her.

She screamed, but it sounded something vaguely like, "Mmmffmm!" Suddenly, she realized, she was receiving her second kiss of the day, this time from a more willing partner than Kevin. Surprisingly strong arms (they smelled like the ocean!) held her perfect body up to a lean, long-limbed one, and a part of her said, Let him, Bella. Let him...you like him, and he is like you...her emerald eyes, open in astonishment at first, began to close. But who was he? A part of her said, it doesn't matter, Bella, he likes you, and he is doing something about it...just enjoy...this part of her was very convincing, and even persuaded her to run her delicate fingers through his curly black hair.

But another part of her persuaded her to kick him, hard, in the crotch. Herman Olymp rolled off of her.

"Ow! What was THAT?" cried the boy, rocking on the ground. "Gods can hurt there too, you know."

"Sorry," she said at first, then, "but even 'gods' should know better than to just start kissing a woman like that. You scared me!"

Herman smiled, despite his pain. "So!" he said, triumphantly. "You're coming with me!"

"For now, yes," she shrugged. "I don't think you're right about my being a god or goddess, or 'The Mother,' or whatever...but you're right about one thing--I'm no good at being a superhero.

"Hmm..." said Herman. "Conditional surrender."

"Also, you should know, you crafty moron," she managed, with a little more spunk than she normally mustered around him, "you should know that I read a lot of literature. When you're too beautiful to get a date, you find more solitary ways to pass the time."

"So?" he said. '

"I get what your silly name means--Hermes, the Olympian."

"Oh, bravo," he clapped, sarcastically.

"You don't REALLY think that's who you are, right?"

"No, not exactly," said Herman, uncomfortably, scratching his neck. "But it is a big part of who I am--just not everything. Divine identity is a little more...fluid than that. But, don't take MY word for it. I'm just the Messenger, after all..."

And with that, he grabbed her hand, and, before she could resist, she was being pulled across what felt simultaneously like water and rock, and through many, many doors. She began to pass out, but before she could, she was sitting on a sofa in a cold room. Five figures stared down at her. It was dark.

"Herman?" she called. What had happened to him?

Suddenly, a child approached. "Welcome to Paragonia," he said. "The heart of this city--of reality, in fact. I am called The Emperor. He bowed to her, and Bella noticed that his left eye was glass. Also, his hair was prematurely grey.

Another form approached--a very tall man this time, and very handsome, she realized. "I am called The Sun," he bellowed, and bowed, very low. Next, a woman of about thirty-five, with olive skin, black hair, and an elaborate headdress. "I am called The Polis," she said. A fat woman, rather old, curtsied at her. "The Moon," she cackled. Her laughter was joined by a rumbling guffaw, as another giant strode toward her. This one had silver hair, and looked quite a bit like Herman. "I am The Wild," he said. "And I believe you've already met my dear son, The Messenger." Bella nodded.

The child approached her again. "Please stand up, woman. We will not hurt you," he said, giving her a look that was half-contemptuous. "Everyone," he said, "I am pleased to introduce to you all the seventh member of our 'little' band. Please bow to The Mother. They all did, and Bella turned around to see if there was a way out behind her. She could see nothing besides the eerie faces. Either, she thought, they really are...gods...of some kind--though God knows what kind--or this is all some elaborate trick. At once, she felt that her arm being taken by Herman.

"I kind of want to go home now," she whispered to him. "This is getting really weird."

"That would be really rude," he whispered to her. "We still need to celebrate." Then, louder, for everyone, "To the mead hall!"

At that instant, the light increased, and the seven of them were at a large table, in the middle of...

"Welcome to T.G.I. Friday's, my name is Pauline. Can I get you all a drink to start you off?" asked a shortish waitress, covered with buttons. She was bending over a table where all seven of them sat, talking.

"Get anything you want," said the grey-haired kid. "It's all on me tonight." They did. Two beers, two cherry cokes, a diet, a milkshake and a red wine.

But before the seven of them drank anything, they flicked the side of their glasses, causing them to ring.

"Transforming them!" said Herman, when she asked what they were doing, "Into ambrosia! To your health!" He swallowed the wine. "Here, I'll do yours too," he said, flicking her beer as well. She, meanwhile, worked out a theory. They were a particularly nerdy and off-beat group of meta-humans--teleporting ones--who compensated themselves for their lack of social skills by pretending to be...but then, they could still talk to her, even the male ones...that was the thing... She took a gulp of beer.

Say. She DID feel different. She took another swallow. She could feel strength, or life, or immortality, or something. Why gods would haunt T.G.I.Friday's was beyond her, but either this was ambrosia, or it was the weirdest beer she had ever tasted. She took another sip, and everything was a blur of eating, dancing with the long-limbed Messenger, exulting in mutual immortality, and the smell of the sea, and her yellow dress going bye-bye as she let herself be, just, happy...

She woke up to the sound of the television, stretched--then suddenly noticed, horrified, that she was naked, and buried herself under alien covers. She looked around her. "Oh, shit!" she said. She had been a fool. At the foot of the bed, she could see Herman's hairy, naked back, his face, apparently, entirely engrossed in the television.

He turned around at once. "Beautiful!" he crowed. "Good morning, my lovely one!'

"Uh...good morning?" she tried.

"Did you have a good night? Your first night as a goddess?"

"Yyyeah. Um. Question."

"Sure, gorgeous."

"WHAT THE FUCK DID YOU DO TO ME?"

"It has many different names," said Herman, grinning, ignoring her obvious distress.

"Herman, or Hermes, or Messenger, or whatever the hell you're called...IT'S called date...rape! You slipped me a roofie...or...or something!"

"Noooo, no, no, no, no," he said, sounding slightly irritated. "It's called getting drunk on sweet LIFE itself, and making wild, passionate love, god-to-goddess, the way it should be. You remember enough of last night to know you were conscious."

Shit. She had to give him that. Even if barely conscious.

"Ambrosia is strong, is all." He dove across the bed toward her, and she jumped up, pulling the covers around her body.

"Where is my dress?" she asked.

"Hey, come here and look at this, on the television," he said, in an amused voice. "Look at what those mortals have gone and done to themselves. It's hilarious."

A reporter on the television was talking. "--condition is highly contagious, and we urge all citizens--particularly female citizens--not to leave their houses until it is over."

"Thanks, Anne," said an anchorman. "Again, for those of you just joining us, an epidemic of obesity appears to be sweeping through the city, as of yesterday evening." Bella sat down on the edge of the bed, making sure she was holding the blanket well over her perfect breasts and legs. The anchorman continued. "The epidemic spreads very rapidly by touch, so it is very important that no one touch anyone who looks as though they may have this disease. It occurs as fat cells multiply--almost instantaneously--throughout a victim's body. Investigators believe it was probably bioengineered, but it may also be the result of some as-yet-unknown superpower. This footage from one earlier such incident.

Bella watched the screen in amazement, as, on the screen, a beautiful, slender Indian woman--had she seen her before? Hadn't she been in some movie?--began to scream, staring at suddenly-pudgy hands, which reached down to hold instantaneous folds of new belly fat. The woman's face, on-screen, became contorted and monstrous, her eyes white and huge as, with a howl of rage, she turned her expanding rump toward the video cameras in an attempt to walk away on legs that had doubled in size. "That was former Bollywood star, R--" Bella suddenly realized, with a shudder, that behind the Indian woman was the metro station on Thomas Street! Glad I didn't go there, she thought. She hugged her graceful body, under the quilt, protectively. Herman laughed. "Look at that!" he said. "It's hilarious!"

"We'll continued to give you the details as we get them," continued the anchor, "but now let's go to the camera crews, who are outside of Guldhelm, where victims are being contained so as to avoid further contagion." Ah, thought Bella. Good. Godspeed to everyone who was rounding up these women. It frightened her to no end to think that her own, perfect, body could somehow billow, like a sail, out of all control, just by being at the wrong place at the wrong time. She felt slightly bad for the women who HAD been so unfortunate, but they couldn't exactly be free to roam around. Also, she knew how vengeful less attractive women could be. Let the fatties loose, and within a few days, the entire city would be full of morbidly obese women. Hospital costs and insurance would rise astronomically, an economic and health crisis would ensue...

Herman turned to her. "Good thing you're with me, eh? Stay here, if you want to."

"Thanks," she said. I think I might." Then, at once, her blood froze. There, on the television, she caught a glimpse of a familiar--and yet, unfamiliar--face. Her roommate Francesca--Lantern--now fatter than she had ever feared becoming--was being herded, along with a number of other hulking women in blue robes--into Guldhelm.

"Francesca!" she whispered. She thought, for a minute, that she should do something--protest, anything--to prevent her friend from being herded into the prison like some criminal. But then she remembered the swelling body of that Indian woman, and peered under the quilt at her own perfect legs, stomach, and breasts, recently held by her first lover. At last, she was loved. She could not risk this--risk losing this--for the sake of a few unfortunate women. Anyway, it was only for a few days, they had said on the news. But just in case, all the same, she'd better stay away from her now-fat friend--even from their house.

"Hey, would you really mind if I stayed with you?" she asked Herman.

He turned around, feigning annoyance. "I SUPPOSE that's okay," he said, taking her hand from the quilt, and kissing it. Grey eyes met Hazel eyes, and he continued to kiss up her arm. "I don't think, though, my goddess-queen, that it's time for you to put that dress back on yet."

"Oh, don't you?" she said, feigning incomprehension. And they were, at once, moving together, like thunder and lightning. And this time, she remembered it. Mostly.

The Mother sat back on her throne, in her oaken room filled with picture frames--some full of beautiful children, some empty--and she pushed again.

"Uuunghh...where...is...Huuuhhhmmmessengr?" she screamed.

A wrinkled, merciful hand cleared a little of the sweat off The Mother's smooth but beaded brow, pushing dark gold curls back out of her face. "Just concentrate on breathing and pushing, dear," said The Moon, sympathetically. "It'll be over soon."

"Yooouuhhh....think....IIIII...dooooon't...knowthat?" Bella retorted. "You think I haven't done enough of this by now?"

"Oh, Honey," said The Moon, looking away from The Mother and around the room at the pictures--of ten children, in all--"I'm afraid you haven't. Not yet." The Mother groaned in pain and rage, then fell back on her pillow. Only she, thought the crone, catching sight of the first tiny head, only she could possibly still look beautiful while in labor. The triplets on the way would bring the total up to thirteen. Thirteen perfect little ones, who would be strong, young gods--who would help the Seven rule the earth. The idea was exhiliarating as it was frightening, for gods did not always cooperate. But the earth badly needed ruling.

"Harvest," spoke a sudden male voice, laughing. As the golden-eyed little one began its scream. "She will be as fertile as her mother, and will bless the earth with crops and withhold them when needed."

"Harvest," repeated The Moon, enveloping the tiny, wriggling arms and legs in yellow cloth. "She's as beautiful as The Mother," she cooed to Bella. "Look."

"Messenger!" screamed The Mother, pushing once again. "Messenger, WHY weren't you here today?"

The Messenger stroked The Mother's moist hair, and kissed her glowing cheek, but she swatted him off. "I am here, honey. This is my part in it all. Your part is the bearing, mine the naming. This is the way--"

"How nice for you!" barked The Mother. "This...unnghhh...isss....SECOND....TIME!" she groaned, sobbing as she delivered her twelfth child. "The second time you haven't been here for the birth!"

Another tiny cry, another godling in the arms of The Moon. "He is Wealth!" shouted Hermes. "He will give or withhold good trade from humans and metahumans." Finishing his pronouncement, he added, "I'm sorry, Honey. You know how busy times are just now...just so much administration has to be..."

"I...ugnng...don't....CARE, Herman!" The Mother said, albeit in a whisper. "You....uughhh...are my hus.....band. YOU....ghhhh....got me into this."

"I know, sweet. And I'm not sorry, both because I love you, and because it had to happen. To be fair, though," he smiled, slightly, "while I certainly claim Wealth, I do think Harvest looks quite a bit more like The Sun. And he is not here."

She nearly fell out off the birth throne trying to punch his face. Moon pulled her back on, shooting a disapproving look at The Messenger. "Not now," she whispered to him. "Just keep pushing, you're almost done, honey," she said to her.

"YOU!" resumed The Mother. "YOU are the one who tricked me into being part of this...this...SICK little arrangement! ALWAYS being FUCKED and pregnant! Always having children crawling out of me! So you're DAMN right you're the one who needs to be here! You son of a BITCH!" For a moment, she reminded the part of The Messenger that was Hermes of his vindictive stepmother. He had seen it before. But this passed.

"Bella, we've talked about this so many times," he said, taking her hand. "It's the only way to save the world. You KNOW we need gods to take control of things. The metahumans, the humans, the blobs and the LOST...they're out of control, and they need gods to rule them again. And you KNOW you're the Fertility...the only one of us that can bear..."

"Yes...I KNOW...all right. And....unnghhh...I....don't....CARE!" Shortly after marrying The Messenger, she had been amazed at the suggestion that she should sleep with some of the other gods. They had explained that it was important to maintain balance of power between them, but even so, she refused. At last, when most governments collapsed, and the Seven became rulers of a very unstable world, she allowed artificial insemination, but a part of her hated all of them for not understanding how repugnant the idea was to a girl who had been human. Everything was so crazy, now. So wrong. "I want my old life!" she screamed.

"Hon, nobody has their old life anymore. Everyone's 'old life' has been sacrificed. I'm sorry for your sacrifices, but they need gods, they need rulers, so that we can restore some semblance of..."

"FUCK....THE....GODS!" she screamed.

"I see a head," cried The Moon. "This one's almost out!"

"Fuck all of you....unnghhh....gods.....I...just...want...to.....aiighhh!...be humanagain!"

"He's out!" cackled The Moon, gathering him up. The Messenger tried to kiss The Mother again, but she turned her face away. He stood up to make his usual birthtime decree"

"This one is..." he began, "this one...is...huh. This one is called... Well, that's strange."

"What is it?" asked The Moon.

"I...I'm not sure why, but I can't find a name for this one. It's a boy." The Messenger sounded perplexed. The Mother even thought she heard a note of resentment in his voice. "This one...very strange, but this one...might not be a god...at all."

"Give him to me!" shouted Bella, with her remaining strength.

"Sure," said The Messenger, relieving himself of the burden, and proudly taking up the other two children, one in each arm. "So strange," he said. "Honey, you were wonderful, as always."

The Mother did not answer. She was looking down into a tiny red face, that to anyone else besides her and The Messenger, would have looked exactly like the other two--perhaps, just slightly, less perfect. The Messenger, his father, had been clueless, but she had read plenty of mythology in her time, and she knew exactly what to name the child.

"Welcome, my little darling boy, to a crazy world" she whispered. "A world you will never rule, and yet of all these children, you are the greatest gift to us, my little Prometheus." She pulled up her shirt and lifted the tiny face to her swollen breast.

"Darling," said The Messenger, holding the other two, "you don't have to do that, you know. We have wet nurses."

"No!" she shouted. "This one is mine. Go ahead and take the other two, if you really want."

The Messenger shrugged. Twenty-first century women, he thought. There was a time, when a mortal girl would have been proud as anything to bear so many children, and to a god, at that. Much less to learn that she herself was a goddess! Especially when her children would save the world, as these two would. He felt hurt by his wife, and distant from her--a distance which he would have gladly reconciled, but she held him away--had held him away for years, though she knew as well as he that times were hard, and required work on both their parts--he in naming, calling order out of disorganization so that communication between gods and men would be possible--and she in bearing, filling the chaotic void with teeming life. Both of their parts were vital, and hers, he admitted, perhaps moreso. They all knew that she was the most important one, and they treated her as such. Why then, this resentment? Was The Emperor right? Was she merely spoiled, like so many of the young people of her generation?

They had been unable--utterly unable, as only a soft, spoiled, decadent generation can be (he had seen it, on a smaller scale, with the Babylonians and the Romans, with the Hapsburgs and the Ottomans)--to cope with the crisis of their time. They had failed the test. Even before the blob epidemic they were becoming soft and flabby. Even before the LOST began their uprising they were walking about dead, anesthetized, apathetic. Before the metahumans came on the scene, they were abusing their power at the expense of the weak.

In the time--less than a second--that it took him to think about these things, he was already across the Courtyard of Ages (where his children played in the branches of the golden apple tree), past the Fountain of Youth, and through five hundred doors, there at the Mountaintop Palace at the Center of Reality. Ah, his heart glowed. The nursery.

Two-year-old Rain, son of The Wild (and, technically, weirdly, his half-sister), was crying as usual, as Wind, her brother, made funny sounds with his mouth. His oldest, Justice, was almost five, and was watching over his siblings with a precocious eye. Genius and Craft, both four, were in the middle of animated conversation, even making puns in ways that did their father proud, as five metahuman nursemaids gave the other little immortals milk, burped and changed and played with them. So these, he thought, would be the ones. He would have to train them well, for they would again bring order out of chaos.

He had been foolish, he thought, to laugh at the epidemic when it began. Out there, in the world, he thought, terrible things were happening--things that even gods and goddesses would not be immune to, though there was cause to hope that their children--nursed with ambrosial milk from the time they were tiny--would.

Though the government of what was, only five years ago! the United States, had done everything they could to contain the epidemic, it had spread like wildfire. This was because for every four women who had decided to be honorable and turn themselves in or had been captured, there were always four who accidentally transmitted it to someone else first, and three who, driven mad by the loss of beauty, would deliberately pass the virus to someone--their husband's mistress, younger women, models--the more beautiful a woman was, the more quickly she was targeted--and the more quickly she willingly passed the virus on. Glad he had rescued The Mother from any such fate, he'd laughed at the fact that within a week of the outbreak, there were no more professional models or actresses in the U.S. He would not have laughed so hard if he'd realized that this would not be another mere disaster. It was the spark that would soon cause the world to go up in flames.

After two weeks, twenty percent of the country's women were infected with the disease. Prisons, hospitals and new "containment centers" swelled with enormous women, as students, wives, doctors, mothers, politicians and media personnel became unable to perform their respective functions.

Meanwhile, the LOST, a small, cannibalistic group of horrific creatures who had lived in obscurity in the city's metros, took advantage of the chaos to mount an unprecedented attack on humanity. People who were bitten by the LOST turned into the hideous creatures, eventually and lost the ability to speak with all vestiges of their humanity, but for a few years they became thin, and sometimes darkly beautiful. Once word got out about this, The Messenger was shocked to see thousands of obese women seeking out the LOST for cosmetic reasons, and the LOST were only too glad to help them, adding to their once-small number.

Obese women--dubbed "the blobs"--who preferred their humanity to a nice figure, as well as the majority of the metahumans, realized that the LOST were becoming more and more of a threat, and they joined forces to fight the ghouls. The close association, however, caused about ninety percent of metahuman superheroines to become obese, and therefore, far less effective fighters. It turned out, however, that women who had become LOST were still able to be affected, moderately, by the epidemic as long as they still resembled humans, and a new strain of fat warrior women with indigo skin and gleaming fangs also, slowly, began to appear.

Power on earth was now split between the LOST, the blobs, the metahumans and ordinary humans, but because individuals often fit more than one of these categories, their choice of loyalties was often, seemingly, arbitrary. Nevertheless, the earth had been drawn and quartered. And they--the gods--multiplying slowly at the heart of their hidden citadel, thanks to The new Mother, would surely turn earth's most tumultuous age into its best. The Messenger looked fondly at these children of the gods, more powerful than metahumans, unable to be affected by blobs or LOST. There had been a verse in some ancient scripture, he remembered, about sons being arrows in their father's quiver. So it would be.

Then--suddenly--an earthquake. Was it coming from the Courtyard? Even as he wondered this, the Messenger was there. It was twilight. Then, bursting from the earth, he saw them--dark, monstrous flesh that defied definition, horrible white fangs and eyes. They began at once to destroy the building, some pummelling it with rock-hard fists, some spraying fire, some working curses, uprooting trees with their mind. He fought with them all, simultaneously, trying to undo the damage, taking the kids back to the nursery, trying to find the other gods as he traded punches with them. But there was one he did not see, until she was above him.

"Messenger!" the voice hissed, and it took all of him there, at once, to see her. The figure flying wingless above him seemed oddly familiar. Her eyes glowed with golden light, but around her, or it, there was deep night. For the second time that day--in his life--he had no idea what a creature was. He could speak no defining word into the darkness.

"Messenger!" she repeated, in an odd accent. "I see you are confused, so let me help you understand what is happening. We are the darkness that is behind every light. We are the Chaos, the Titans, the Hundred-Handed, the Formless...and we are the unravelling of all your plans." The Messenger looked around him. By now, all the gods and their children--though he did not see Bella--had been gathered there by huge, super-powered women of the night. He began to understand...

"You understand nothing," spoke the cold, oppressive, fleshy darkness above him. "YOU thought you were above US all this time. You stood back and let our nations--our bodies--our very souls--go to waste, while you plotted to take advantage of it all, and impose your ill-conceived New World Order. But though the darkness wrestles with itself, you should have known that it always gathers together against the Light. Witness your enemies reconciled, contraries and lines blurred in massive dark bodies, filled with primal power equal to your own. Witness your household captured and children scattered to the wind, your palace shattered and wasted. We will not allow the gods to rule us again. As you forsook us, we will forsake you, and you will never again limit, define or name--"

"Francesca?" The Messenger heard his wife, and he was suddenly afraid for her.

The form above him became slightly less dark, and turned. "Who is that?" called the icy, accented voice. Was it--was it an Italian accent?

"I am The Mother," said his golden-haired goddess, serenely, queenly.

"Ah, so you are the one who--wait--Bella? Bella Hauge? Is that you? YOU are The Mother?" The Messenger could make out a fat, dark face hovering above him now. It looked puzzled, though the other women--along with a few metahuman LOST males--continued to destroy the celestial palace.

"Francesca, what's happened to you?" said Bella, approaching the form.

"Bella! Stay away!" shouted Messenger. "She can infect you, still!"

"Yes, I can!" laughed the form. "I can and I will, now. How could you have betrayed your kind, Bella? How could you have joined with these so-called gods? I assumed you had died--we all did--all those years ago. This is far worse. You've betrayed metahumans--betrayed your own kind, scheming to lord it over all of us."

Bella took The Messenger's hand. Her own was still clammy from childbed, and it clutched his in its weakness. "I'm sorry," she said to Francesca. "I fell in love, and I was so frightened of becoming...becoming..."

The form lowered itself to the ground and The Messenger was surprised at how human the face now looked. Also, how...understanding? "Of becoming like me," she said. "I don't blame you, but Bella, look at YOU. They've made you stupidly, weakly dependent on them, dominated BY them, just as they plan to do to the rest of us. Do not fear becoming like me; fear remaining like yourself."

"Bella," said The Messenger, tremblingly. "Don't listen to her, it's..."

"Husband. Shhh," said Bella.

"I remember," continued Bella's altered roommate, "how heartbroken I was after...after THIS happened to me, the first time." She gripped a fold of her fat between her clawed fingers. "Jack left me...left me just like that. We were going to be married, you remember."

"I remember."

"Well, when that happened, I was inconsolable. But slowly, slowly, I began to realize how WEAK I had been. To depend on a man like that--I was so pathetic. When I chose to become one of the LOST, as well, it wasn't so that I could be some man's toy again--some pathetic dropper of babies. Don't you see," she said, fangs glistening in a smile,"for the first time, women truly are empowered. WE are the stronger ones, now, not the men."

"But society is coming apart..." started Bella. "I've seen that much."

"A society that was oppressive, perpetuating hierarchy, slavery and misogyny for thousands of years. Now, at last, we are free of being sexualized objects," she said, stroking her enormous belly "--to all but a few weird perverts, that is. And we are free of domination, by men or gods." Francesca held out a claw, glowing with cold darkness. "When I look at you, I see exactly the creature I would have--gladly, pathetically--become. And here you are, popping children out--being used by these old, patriarchal gods to perpetuate their so-called 'order.'"

"I..." but Bella was speechless. Was it really possible that her now-huge, soulless, empowered roommate pitied HER? She looked across the courtyard at her trembling children. Who knew what would happen to them, and yet...

"Bella, I don't blame you," said Francesca, "because you said you fell in love. When I was more naive, and...smaller...and the epidemic broke out, I would probably have made the same choice. But now, you have an option. Join us."

"What?" said Bella.

"Give up your so-called 'beauty.' That standard is really just a need to be validated by men and gods, causing alienation--give it up, and become one with us. Cleave to the Titans, the chaos, the darkness."

Bella felt The Messenger's hand tighten around her own. She pulled her hand away from her lean husband and took a step toward her hulking, former roommate. "I betrayed you," she said. "I'm sorry."

"We are the Chaos," said the fanged mouth. We cannot offer you forgiveness or redemption, as gods claim to. You cannot placate us. You can only join us, and thereby be loved by us."

"Bella, please! Remember your children!" screamed The Messenger.

"I am," said Bella, taking another step toward the LOST metahuman blob. Toward Francesca. She thought of the many, many children, whom she had borne, and barely known, for so many years. Would the gods really do this--make all women mere "mothers," instead of letting them have power, agency? But then, she thought of Prometheus--merely human Prometheus--would the Chaos show mercy, in the end, to anything that did not join it? Including mere humans? She looked again at her tiny waist, a divine incubator, nearly perfectly flat already. She looked at her husband, at all the gods, whom she so hated and loved. She had never particularly liked the look of most of them. She would, she realized, give up her body, surrendering to either fate. But did both require her humanity?

Everything was falling down, around her, but surely, if she chose him, The Messenger could help her escape. Francesca, icily, said, "The Chaos is hungry, always hungry, Bella. You must stop thinking about your choice. You must make one, now, or I will make it." Saying that, she reached toward her.

The Messenger shouted.

Closing tear-filled eyes, The Mother, Freya, Bella Hauge...

...chose.

Felicity loved a good mid-afternoon run. Her mentor at the Academy of Heroic Arts had been one of those Yoda-Miagi types who insisted that they NOT use their powers whenever possible. As a result, she'd been sent on many a training mission, expected to run, but not allowed to warp space while she did so. She still thought the whole idea had been idiotic. The result was, that, at the end of the year, she'd had no more control over her powers of speed than she'd had going in--even if she had lost the college fifteen--and then some. On the other hand, she'd come to enjoy running--the normal, slow way--to the point where she was now addicted to that euphoric feeling you got after doing about a mile or so.

Her phone was going off. She stopped, pulling it from her waistband.

"Hello?"

"Hey, Feliss?" came her roommate's voice. "It's Bella. Um...there's something going on over here that you should check out."

"What is it?"

"Just some kind of disturbance at the metro on Thomas Street. I'd go, but my powers aren't exactly..."

Felicity rolled her eyes. Bella called herself "Freya" after the Norse goddess of love and beauty. Really, the only thing she was able to do with her power was cause men to drool and go momentarily comatose. She was surprised she had ever graduated, and even more surprised that she had managed to stop a supervillain, once. Felicity, called "The Blur," had stopped about twenty-three, by contrast.

"Sure, Bell. I'll be right over."

First, she thought, a quick change. She loved her power, she thought, as a warp field formed around her, and immediately she was running up the street, opening the door of her house, washing her hair, (admiring--for less than a second--her lean, muscular figure, heart-shaped face with its thin, graceful lips, framed by long brown hair), sliding on her favorite jeans, sneakers and costume top (people only wore the leotards for photo ops), and now she was The Blur, speeding down Aiken toward Thomas Street, where her perfect, blonde roommate was waiting for her in a tiny yellow summer dress. In all, the journey took about a minute.

"What kept you so long?" teased Bella.

"Screw you. What's the problem?"

"Damned if I know," Bella said, tossing her curls, dismissively. "Sounds explosivey."

Felicity looked over to the metro entrance. People, spooked, streamed out, along with smoke, but no one looked injured yet. "Hmm. Looks explosivey," she said. "I'll be right back."

The metro entrance, people and steps blurred past her. The smoke seemed to come from a door somewhere beyond the tracks, which she was able to gain enough momentum to leap over. She rocketed through the door, noticed, with a shudder, the crouching forms of the LOST crouching around a dead man. She realized with a chill that they were eating him, but she still couldn't see what the source of the explosion was. She raced past them, reluctant to turn her back. She was in a laboratory of some kind, where a voluminous amount of smoke issued from an entire panel of machinery.

"I didn't know technology still looked like that," Blur said. "I guess that's the answer to our riddle. Now, I guess I'd better grab that poor man's body. What was he doing back here? What is this place? And...what is that?" A bright light, issuing from one of the more odd-looking machines, seemed to be bouncing off metal walls. And now, it came toward her. Blur was fast, and though she could see light moving, it often moved quicker than her.

As she turned to run, she felt something strike her on the back of her head, knocking her over. Getting up, she ran past the ghouls in the hallway, who were just turning their heads in her direction, out of the metro and into the sun.
